text: Flooding in Newton Stewart, Hawick, and Peebles has caused widespread damage, with many businesses and homes affected, and officials working to assess the full cost of the damage and implement flood prevention measures.
A fire broke out at a Holiday Inn in Northern Ireland, engulfing two tour buses carrying passengers from Germany, China, and Taiwan, with police investigating the deliberate cause.
Lewis Hamilton secured pole position at the Bahrain Grand Prix, beating Nico Rosberg by 0.077 seconds, as Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel finished third ahead of teammate Kimi Raikkonen.
John Edward Bates, a 67-year-old former scout leader and police officer, is on trial for 22 charges of indecency with a child, including allegations of sexual abuse of four male complainants.
A man being treated at a Turkish hospital threatened to shoot himself and others, prompting an evacuation and a police negotiation, which ended with the man alone in the room.
Glasgow Warriors defeated the Dragons 22-15, with Simone Favaro's try in the final minute securing the win, as the visitors' error count ultimately proved costly despite a strong performance.
A 31-year-old woman, Veronica Vanessa Chango-Alverez, was killed and another man injured when an Audi A3 crashed into a bus stop in Streatham, London, on Saturday morning.
Belgian cyclist Antoine Demoitie, 25, died after colliding with a motorbike during the Gent-Wevelgem race, sparking calls for improved safety measures to prevent similar incidents.

Manchester City's Ilkay Gundogan, recovering from a knee injury, is optimistic about the upcoming season, but will not rush his return, aiming to feel safe and confident before getting back on the field.
A man in his 20s was seriously injured in a car crash on the A127 in Essex, suffering a head injury and suspected fractures, and was airlifted to hospital.
Hurricane Patricia, classified as a Category 5 storm, makes landfall in Mexico, marking the first of its kind to hit the mainland since 1959.

Researchers from Bastille Networks discovered vulnerabilities in wireless mice that allowed attackers to spoof signals and control computers as if they were sitting in front of them, putting users at risk.

Murray and Burrell, a 92-year-old construction company, went into administration due to adverse trading conditions, resulting in the loss of 38 jobs, with some staff potentially finding new employment with a nearby firm.

The European Commission has launched an investigation into Luxembourg's tax deal with Amazon, citing concerns that the arrangement may have granted the company an unfair advantage and violated EU state aid rules.

The Balmoral Show, a three-day event celebrating farming, food, and family fun, returns to Balmoral Park in Northern Ireland for its 148th year, featuring local produce, livestock, and entertainment for all ages.
Nigel Mosley is suing Google for breaching his privacy by hosting images of him at a private sex party, which were originally published in a now-defunct newspaper.
Eddie Jackson, a 28-year-old Bath-born player, will miss the Dragons' Pro12 match against Munster due to injury, leaving a void in the team's back-row.

The UK government has announced a three-year funding package for the Cornish Language Partnership, ensuring the survival of the critically endangered language, with long-term support expected to come from Cornwall.
Monaco's coach Leonardo Jardim, who led the team to the French league title and Champions League semi-finals, has decided to stay with the club despite receiving offers from other teams.

The Nicaraguan government's election, won by President Daniel Ortega with 72.5% of the vote, was deemed flawed and unfair by the US State Department due to lack of international observers and opposition suppression.
The South African government has announced a task team to address the growing issue of "corrective rape" against lesbians, following a petition signed by over 170,000 people worldwide.
Oil-producing nations meet in Qatar to discuss production freeze, but stocks fall amid concerns over oversupply, weak economic data, and losses in energy and technology sectors.
US biologists have found that the vibrant blue color in tarantulas is not driven by sexual selection, but rather evolved independently at least eight times due to its importance in visual signaling.

The German prosecutors found internet searches on co-pilot Andreas Lubitz's tablet about suicide methods, cockpit doors, and security provisions, suggesting he intentionally crashed the Germanwings flight.
Radio DJ Chris Fox, 54, denies eight counts of indecent assault and two counts of sexual assault, claiming "horseplay" with colleagues was consensual and not inappropriate.
Tottenham midfielder Dele Alli will miss several weeks of action after twisting his knee in a collision with a teammate, according to manager Mauricio Pochettino.

A Jehovah's Witnesses elder, Mark Sewell, sexually abused his niece and a family friend, but the organization's internal justice system failed to take action, leading to a 14-year prison sentence only after decades of abuse.
Greece's bailout agreement, approved by Germany and set to total €86bn, has been criticized by former Finance Minister Varoufakis as a "greatest disaster of macroeconomic management ever".

The International Paralympic Committee has opened proceedings against Russia's National Paralympic Committee due to a report alleging a widespread doping program, with a decision on any ban expected by August 1.
Ben, a 24-year-old former England under-20 international, has joined the Exiles on an undisclosed contract, bringing Championship experience to the team.
Manor Marussia F1 team has secured investment from Ovo boss Stephen Fitzpatrick and appointed former Sainsbury's CEO Justin King as interim chairman, aiming to be competitive in the upcoming season.

The Welsh government and Liberal Democrats agreed to a £39m stimulus package to boost the economy, with funding for apprenticeships, school upgrades, and road improvements, despite criticism from opposition parties.
Former UK Prime Minister Sir John Major warned that Brexit will be a "historic mistake" and urged the government to adopt a more diplomatic approach in negotiations with the EU.
The UK government is set to cap benefits at 1% for three years, sparking controversy as Labour argues it will result in a real-terms cut in support for millions of working families.
A hole in a sewer under a railway track in Forest Hill has caused widespread disruptions to Southern, Thameslink, and London Overground services, with repairs expected to take until Wednesday.
Manchester City defeated Everton 2-0 at Etihad Stadium, with Mario Balotelli and James Milner scoring in the second half to move the team to the top of the Premier League.

Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is under fire for claiming to have met a target to reduce six-week delays in discharging patients, despite Labour saying the target has not been met for over three years.
The European Court of Justice ruled that the UK's overflow pipes in Wales broke clean water laws in a conservation area, ordering the UK to pay legal costs and improve the system.
Pope Francis arrived in Cuba, marking the first visit by a Latin American pope, and hailed improving ties with the US as an example of reconciliation, ahead of a four-day visit to the island.
Rangi Chase, a 31-year-old half-back, has joined Widnes Vikings on loan from Castleford Tigers, seeking regular playing time and a fresh start after being dropped from the Tigers' plans.
Cricket Scotland chief executive Roddy Smith is stepping down after 10 years, citing a desire for a fresh challenge, leaving the organization in good health and with a growing game.
Sunderland manager Sam Allardyce is being considered for the England job, despite controversy surrounding his potential appointment, with the FA expected to make a decision soon.
Wales defeated Argentina 24-20, with Leigh Halfpenny's 14 points with the boot proving the difference, as the Pumas refused to give up despite being down by eight points at one stage.
The UK's Department for Culture, Media and Sport has designated the Bulford Kiwi monument and the Terrain Model of Messines as scheduled monuments to protect New Zealand's First World War heritage.
Two prisoners at HMP Wayland, a Category C men's prison in Norfolk, attempted to escape and attack officers, but were "quickly apprehended" and face additional time added to their sentences.
Chris Sutton, a former teammate of Tim Sherwood, believes the Villa manager deserves more time to turn the team around and is confident he can get it right with a settled system and continuity.
Welsh Transport Minister Edwina Hart plans to introduce measures to streamline the system and cut fraud, following a rise in rejections of disability benefit claims by local authorities.
Life expectancy for 65-year-olds in England has increased, with men expected to live an additional 19 years and women 21 years, but many elderly people still live in poor health.
Nottinghamshire Police confirm 530 of 636 reported crimes of sexual, physical, and emotional abuse occurred on council property between the 1940s and 1990s.
The Women's FA Cup quarterfinals have been drawn, featuring top-flight teams Chelsea, Manchester City, Arsenal, and Liverpool, with the winners set to receive £4,000 in prize money.
Cheltenham Town won their seventh game in eight, with Holman and Wright each scoring twice, as they defeated Bromley 4-1 in the National League, staying second in the table.

Jean Charles de Menezes, a Brazilian electrician, was fatally shot by London police on July 22, 2005, after being mistaken for a suicide bomber and was later found to have been living in the UK illegally.
Glasgow City Council plans to increase its council tax by 3% to raise £7m, citing a budget gap of £67m, while protecting frontline services and vulnerable households.
Sustainable Shetland plans to seek a judicial review of the Scottish government's approval of a 370MW wind farm, citing concerns over its size and impact on the landscape.
Ugandan opposition leader Bobi Wine, who lost the recent election to President Yoweri Museveni, was charged with treason and arrested after appearing in court in Moroto.
The British and Irish Lions secured a 23-21 win over Australia in the first Test, with George North and Alex Cuthbert scoring tries, despite a late push from the Wallabies.
Germany coach Joachim Low has selected a 27-man squad for the European Championship, with Marco Reus and Julian Brandt among the notable absentees due to injury concerns.
Fifa President Sepp Blatter and former Uefa President Michel Platini are accused of making a $2m payment in 2011, with both denying wrongdoing and Platini still planning to run for Fifa president.

John Higgins reached the World Championship semi-finals for the first time since 2011, defeating Kyren Wilson 13-6 and setting up a match against Stephen Maguire or Barry Hawkins for a spot in the final.
Pte Paul Wilkinson, a 16-year-old soldier, told an inquest he spoke with Pte Cheryl James 20 minutes before she was found dead, asking her to choose between him and her boyfriend.
A 57-year-old US citizen is on trial for allegedly paying a 15-year-old girl and her friend for sex and engaging in sexual activity with the younger girl, claiming the sex was consensual.
Vandalism on 11 BT cables in Ealing on Saturday affected thousands of customers in London and the South East, with most reconnected but engineers still working to resolve the issue.
South African athlete Caster Semenya is a top contender in the 800m event at the Olympics, with coach Maria Mutola praising her speed and tactical ability in the semi-finals.
Lawsuits filed against SXSW organizers claim they failed to provide adequate traffic safety measures, leading to a fatal car crash at the music festival that killed four people and injured 23.
British sailors Saskia Clark and Hannah Mills won the Olympic gold medal in the women's 470 event at Rio, improving on their silver medal finish in London.
German fencer Alexander Kruse won the foil event at the Shanghai World Cup, defeating Italy's Alessio Foconi 15-8 to rise to world number five and claim his first major title.

Ineos plans to increase ethylene production at Scottish and Norwegian sites, create 300 new jobs, and boost self-sufficiency in key plastics-building blocks through investments in new propylene unit and expanded crackers.
Uber's CEO Travis Kalanick's future is uncertain after the company's board voted to adopt a report's recommendations, which may lead to changes in his leadership or a leave of absence.

English Heritage has approved the replacement of Charminster's 16th-century bridge with a new one featuring larger arches, using original bricks and parapets, to improve river flow and reduce flood risk.
Chelsea's 3-0 win at Leicester City, despite the absence of star striker Diego Costa, strengthens their position at the top of the Premier League table, seven points clear of second-place Tottenham.
Scottish footballer McGregor was fined £500 and banned from driving for 12 months after being caught driving under the influence with a blood alcohol level of 78mg.
Dan Evans, the 23-year-old Briton, lost to Tommy Robredo in the US Open third round, failing to convert two set points on his own serve in the fourth set.

The Indian Supreme Court's decision to uphold the death penalty for Mohammad Ajmal Amir Qasab, the 2008 Mumbai attacks' sole surviving gunman, has reignited debate over capital punishment's effectiveness and morality.

The Hoegh Osaka, a 51,000-tonne vehicle transporter, is being pumped out of 3,000 tonnes of water, with operations delayed due to poor weather conditions and a goal to remove the ship from the Bramble Bank sandbank by Sunday.
Researchers have discovered a diamond from Brazil that contains a mineral with 1% water, suggesting that there may be as much water trapped in the Earth's interior as in all the oceans.

Peter Whittle endorses Paul Nuttall to lead UKIP, citing his experience, dedication, and popularity among members, as the party seeks a new leader amid a tumultuous time following the Brexit referendum.
Aberdeen-born artist is awarded the RSGS's Livingstone Medal for raising awareness of the global HIV/AIDS pandemic, a prestigious honor with a history dating back to 1901.
News organizations sue FBI to reveal the identity of the security firm that helped unlock the iPhone of San Bernardino killer Syed Rizwan Farook, citing public interest and transparency.
Vernon Cotter, Scotland's coach, reflects on his two-and-a-half-year tenure, citing cultural influences, team progress, and his decision to leave the role after the Six Nations.
At least 358 people died in a fire at a Honduran prison, with officials still trying to identify the victims and investigate the cause of the blaze that broke out on Tuesday.
The Willow Tea Rooms Trust is refurbishing the historic Sauchiehall Street building, which was designed by Mackintosh, to restore it to its original grandeur and reopen as a tea room.
Michelle Obama rode in a car for the first time in seven years, singing along to hits by Beyonce and Stevie Wonder during a karaoke episode of The Late, Late Show with James Corden.
England's batsmen struggled, making only 134-8, before a dramatic finish saw Chris Morris score two off the last ball to secure a South Africa win in the first T20 international.

The UK government has announced changes to Personal Independence Payments, which will affect 160,000 people with disabilities, amid criticism that the new rules will restrict benefits and contradict court judgments.
Olly Murs and Caroline Flack will host The Xtra Factor, a spin-off show, alongside new judges Nick Grimshaw and Rita Ora, replacing Louis Walsh, Mel B, and Dermot O'Leary.
William Hill's pre-tax profits fell 35% to £78.7m in the first half of the year due to increased gambling duties and one-off costs, despite a slight revenue increase.

Widnes Vikings remain top of the Super League table after seven games, thanks to their strong defense and improved play, which has seen them score 230 points and concede fewer than Wigan and Warrington.

The Great Barrier Reef is experiencing its worst coral bleaching event on record, with only 7% of the reef showing no signs of bleaching, largely due to rising water temperatures caused by global warming.

Manchester United signs Uruguayan defender Guillermo Varela, 20, on a five-year deal, marking manager David Moyes's first signing, with the player set to join the team after the Under-20 World Championships.
Granada CF suffered a 2-1 defeat to Real Sociedad, sealing their relegation from the top flight, with Carlos Vela and Juanmi scoring for the hosts.
Twelve men accused of planning and carrying out the 2006 Mumbai train bombings that killed 189 and injured 800 are set to be sentenced, with some facing the death penalty or life in prison.
A new study by Cancer Research UK found that over a third of Scots eat confectionery daily, highlighting the need for urgent action to tackle obesity and prevent related cancers.

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker declared August 13 "Purple Hearts for Healing" Day in honor of a 12-year-old girl who was stabbed 19 times by two classmates who believed they were acting on behalf of the fictional character Slenderman.
Greek coach Skafidas was banned for 10 years for nine rule violations, including abusing his position and manipulating sprinter Wilson's doping tests.
The Scottish government has launched a judge-led inquiry into the Edinburgh trams project, which has been plagued by cost overruns, delays, and disruption to homes and businesses.
Valentino Rossi, a nine-time world champion, collided with a fan while riding a motorcycle at the Valencia Grand Prix, with the fan considering pressing charges, citing intentional behavior.
Edinburgh Rugby's 23-year-old player, Kennedy, has undergone surgery for an ongoing shoulder complaint and is expected to be sidelined for up to six months.
North Cumbria University Hospitals NHS Trust is considering removing consultant-led maternity services from Whitehaven's West Cumberland Hospital due to concerns over infrastructure and safety.
Rangers' former player Morten Lovenkrands says reaching the Scottish Cup final should motivate the team, rather than focusing on beating Celtic, who have not lost a domestic game this season.
The PSNI will close off-licences in the Holylands area of Belfast from 16:00-21:00 GMT on March 17 to help keep people safe, following disturbances on St Patrick's Day in 2016.
South Wales Police are investigating a robbery at Lloyds Bank in Canton, Cardiff, where a suspect was caught on CCTV and is described as a 50-60-year-old man with black hair and black clothing.

The British Army is creating a new 77th Brigade, a unit of reservists and regular troops, to focus on psychological operations and information warfare, drawing inspiration from the Chindits who fought in Burma during World War Two.
Garry Allen, 33, has been charged with causing death by dangerous driving after a fatal crash on the A52 in 2016 that killed 25-year-old Christopher Williams.
Sarah Sands, 32, is on trial for murdering her 77-year-old neighbor Michael Pleasted, who was accused of abusing three boys, after she allegedly stabbed him eight times in his flat.

Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International accused Australia of intentionally allowing abuse of asylum seekers on Nauru to deter others from attempting to reach the country, citing reports of rape, assault, and poor living conditions.

The leaders of the Welsh Conservative, Labour, Liberal Democrat, and Plaid Cymru parties campaigned on healthcare issues ahead of the Welsh election, with each party promising different solutions to improve the NHS.
A 13ft by 9ft wooden beach hut in Abersoch, Wales, has sold for £250,000, a record price for the area, despite having no electricity or water and restrictions on overnight stays.
Third-party websites have been exploiting a bug in FIFA 17's Ultimate Team mode, allowing players to earn unlimited coins and items without playing the game.

The Clifton Village residents' parking signs were installed on Grade II* listed railings, sparking complaints and concerns from English Heritage about potential damage to the conservation area's character.

During the devastating Portuguese forest fires, emergency responders struggled to communicate due to failures in the Siresp network, leading to delays and hampering rescue efforts, resulting in 64 deaths.

Fifa's presidential election is underway, with several candidates vying for the top spot, including Michel Platini, Prince Ali bin al-Hussein, and Shaikh Salman bin Ebrahim Al Khalifa, amidst corruption allegations against current President Sepp Blatter.

The Luas red line in Dublin has introduced a new camera system that issues fines and penalty points to motorists who run red lights at the Blackhall Place-Benburb Street junction, reducing collisions with trams.
A 18-year-old man, dressed as a superhero, was charged with entering a restricted area at Sunderland's Stadium of Light during a match against Manchester City.

The Queen of the UK visited the former Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, where Anne Frank died, and met with survivors and liberators, paying respects to the victims of the camp's horrific conditions and mass killings.
Dumfries and Galloway Council is investing almost £2.5m in a harbour redevelopment project, aiming to transform the area into a marina complex and regenerate the surrounding town.
Aston Villa manager Rémi Garde's team lost to West Ham, with Garde refusing to comment on a penalty appeal and a red card, citing it's "not the time" to discuss.

Dane County District Attorney Ishmael Ozanne cleared police officer Matt Kenny of charges in the fatal shooting of 19-year-old Tony Robinson, citing a "lawful use of deadly police force" in a self-defense scenario.
The UK government has named and shamed 198 employers who failed to pay minimum wage to over 3,000 workers, with a total debt of £3.5m, and all arrears have since been paid back.
The M4 motorway in Wales will be closed between junctions 25A and 26 from Monday to Friday nights for maintenance work on the Brynglas tunnels until February 2018.

Thousands of Lyssa Zampa tropical moths, native to South East Asia, have been sighted in Malaysia and Singapore, causing a stir among residents and sparking online debate about their presence and potential impact.
Conservationists say that the Madagascar pochard, a critically endangered duck species, is on the brink of extinction due to human activities, with only 25 individuals remaining in the wild.

Ireland's cricket team has announced its squad for a week-long T20 tournament in the United Arab Emirates, featuring eight associate countries, with several experienced players returning after injuries and absences.
Hywel Dda University Health Board plans to reduce the hours of its paediatric ambulatory care unit at Withybush Hospital by four hours a day due to a shortage of consultant paediatricians.

The match between Stirling and City saw both teams have scoring chances, with Lewis McLear striking the post and Steven Doris clearing a header off his own line, while Darren Smith fired wide for the hosts.
Kazakhstan, a vast and diverse country, has experienced rapid economic growth since independence in 1991, driven by oil investment and led by authoritarian President Nursultan Nazarbayev.

British athletes compete in various events at the Paralympics, including swimming, athletics, table tennis, and wheelchair basketball, with some achieving notable results and others falling short of expectations.

Wimbledon has signed former Crewe centre-half Tom Mitchell-King, 27, who was released by Crewe due to injuries, and has also taken up contract options on forward Luke Moore and defender Fraser Franks.
DUP leader Arlene Foster has offered to meet with Irish language advocates, saying she wants to understand those who love the language and are not using it as a political tool.

Scottish midfielder James McFadden has signed a two-year deal with Hull City after leaving Chicago, citing difficulties with international travel and a desire to achieve something in British football.
Elisabeth Christie won the 500m speed skating event at the Calgary World Cup, finishing ahead of Canadian Jamie Macdonald and Netherlands' Yara van Kerkhof with a time of 42.565 seconds.
Yacht manager Douglas Innes is on trial for manslaughter by gross negligence after four men died when their yacht capsized in the North Atlantic due to a faulty keel.

Swansea City's new signing Borja Bastón, a 23-year-old forward from Atletico Madrid, has joined the team for a club-record £15m fee and is eager to make a good impression and earn a call-up to the Spanish national team.

Sporting Khalsa, a semi-professional Asian football club from the West Midlands, is set to face FC United of Manchester in the FA Cup fourth qualifying round, seeking to make history by reaching the first round for the first time.
A 45-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of a racially aggravated offense and possessing an offensive weapon during a Rosh Hashanah celebration in Greater Manchester.
Scottish Labour leader Johann Lamont resigns, citing a need for a "real discussion" about the party's future, amid infighting and criticism of her leadership and Westminster colleagues.
A fuel shortage in France caused by a strike has sparked a humorous reaction on social media, with users renaming film titles to reference the shortage and popular culture icons.
Bank of America reports a 5% rise in consumer banking profits and a 13% increase in residential mortgage lending, while Wells Fargo sees its first profit rise in three quarters.

The documentary "Mr Alzheimers and Me" follows three young people sharing their personal stories about living with grandparents who have dementia, a progressive brain disease causing memory loss and cognitive decline.
A man rescued a cat named Francee from a tiny cavity space in his new home's wall after hearing her meowing and using a drill, chisel, and hammer to free her.
A Bangladeshi man, Shamsul Arefin, was found guilty of modern-day slavery after forcing four people to work at a Scottish hotel for years, subjecting them to exploitation and abuse.
London Paramount, a 900-acre theme park, is being delayed from opening in 2020 to 2021 due to ongoing research into traffic and environmental issues.
French PM Manuel Valls and US Secretary of State John Kerry accuse Russia of killing civilians in Syria, while Russia denies targeting civilians and insists it is battling terrorists.
Leyton Orient faces a winding-up petition from Revenue & Customs for non-payment of tax, with the club's fans launching a crowd-funding campaign to raise £250,000 to settle the debt.
Moby's new album, "The Systems Are Failing", marks a departure from his usual electronic sound, embracing a faster, more aggressive post-punk style.
Researchers at Cardiff University found that students who took the Welsh Baccalaureate were 15% less likely to achieve a first or 2:1 degree, despite being more likely to get into university.
Tiger Woods shot a 1-over-par 73 in the first round of his charity golf event, nine shots behind leader JB Holmes, after making several mistakes and double bogeys on the back nine.
A 38-year-old man, Shaun Murphy, died in hospital after being found injured in Wythenshawe, and a 23-year-old man is in custody for questioning in connection with the incident.
The Freedom Party in Austria has filed a legal challenge to the presidential election results, citing irregularities in postal voting and alleging that up to 570,000 ballots may have been affected.

A report recommends splitting the roles of Jersey's Bailiff, who serves as both head of the legal system and president of the States, citing concerns about judicial independence and clarity in international representation.
Rebels launched a coordinated assault on government-held areas of Aleppo, firing hundreds of rockets and shells, and made small advances despite government claims of repelling the attack.
Isabella Rossellini, daughter of film legends, showcased her directorial debut at the 2008 Berlin Film Festival and will be part of the 2011 judging panel, led by Werner Herzog.
Three Americans were flown out of Yemen's capital, Sanaa, after being detained by Houthi rebels on suspicion of spying, following a US government request for Oman's help.

Inmarsat's Global Xpress satellite, designed to provide fast and reliable broadband connectivity, is set to launch on August 28 on a Proton rocket after a failed previous launch and subsequent review.
Fernando Alonso won the Spanish Grand Prix, his second victory of the season, and moved into third in the standings, 17 points behind leader Sebastian Vettel.
A crash between a Lamborghini and a Ferrari in Shanghai left one person injured, with the cause unknown, but witnesses suggested the tunnel was often used for drag racing.
Carnival's shares rose 3% to £41.45 due to higher ticket prices and increased onboard spending, while Lloyds bank and other financial institutions also saw gains.
British judokas Oates and Davis lost in the semi-finals and bronze-medal matches, respectively, at the European Judo Championships.
Developers plan a 100MW pumped storage hydro scheme at Glenmuckloch, Scotland, which could generate power for over a century and create two reservoirs connected by a tunnel with a pump-turbine.
The 2015 UK election is expected to be unpredictable, with local factors playing a significant role in individual seats, challenging traditional two-party dynamics and national poll predictions.

East Sussex Healthcare Trust, which runs two hospitals, is likely to be placed into special measures due to inadequate performance and lack of improvement despite previous criticism and management issues.

UK Conservative leader David Cameron announces plans to build 100,000 new homes for first-time buyers, exempt from some taxes and only available to those under 40 who work hard and earn a modest income.
The UK Parliament is set for a busy week with votes on Sunday trading, crime bills, and employment support allowance, as well as debates on women's representation and international issues.
A former pupil of Haggerston Girls' School in Hackney, London, claims she may have been exposed to asbestos in the music room, which could have contributed to her diagnosis with mesothelioma.
Ulster's Chris Henry has signed a contract extension until 2017, committing to the province and aiming to win a trophy and secure a spot in Joe Schmidt's Ireland World Cup squad.
American Jimmy Walker and Kevin Streber share the lead at the US PGA Championship after shooting 9-under-par 63s, with Jason Day and Henrik Stenson tied for third.
AirAsia posted a net loss of $95.8 million due to foreign exchange losses and Indonesia operations, despite efforts to increase capacity in the fourth quarter to meet holiday demand.

David Anderson QC, the independent reviewer of terrorism legislation, criticizes the UK government's counter-terrorism bill, citing concerns about the lack of court oversight and potential infringement on civil liberties.

Hundreds of students at Jawaharlal Nehru University protest the arrest of their student union leader Kanhaiya Kumar, who is facing sedition charges for allegedly raising "anti-India" slogans at an event.
New Zealand's Luke Ronchi has replaced Sharjeel Khan in the Pakistan Super League, joining the team for the remaining 14 T20 group games.
Police closed the Glen Road in Northern Ireland after an unknown object was reported on the road, but searches yielded nothing and the road has since reopened.
This article is an update notice, informing readers that a breaking news story is being updated and will be published shortly, with instructions on how to receive further updates.
The Singapore Grand Prix is a unique and desirable race on the F1 calendar, offering a thrilling night-time atmosphere, challenging track, and a blend of business and cultural experiences.
A man with multiple sclerosis was admitted to a hospital three times without his knowledge or consent, with a "do not resuscitate" order placed on his file each time.
Northern Ireland's First Minister and Deputy First Minister met in Enniskillen, away from Belfast, to discuss local issues and showcase the region's attractions to the public.
Crystal Palace's Wilfried Zaha responded to racist abuse from Manchester United and Liverpool fans on Instagram, saying they could continue to call him a "black monkey" if it made their day better.
Labour won the Dunfermline by-election with a majority of 2,873 votes, taking the seat from the SNP, which had held it since 2011, in a contest focused on local issues.
Liam McDonald, 31, takes over as Solihull Moors manager, leaving Hednesford Town, and will lead the team in their FA Cup replay against Yeovil, with Keith Bertschin as head coach.
The BBC is inviting readers to share their photographs of Scotland, accepting submissions between June 16-23 and encouraging use of the hashtag #bbcscotlandpics.

The UK's Metropolitan Police is considering using trained birds of prey to take down drones, following successful trials in the Netherlands, to combat concerns over drone use by criminals and potential terrorist groups.
A trial oyster farming project off the coast of Porlock Bay has been a "brilliantly successful" endeavor, securing a top quality rating and expected to sell thousands of oysters locally.

Wales' coach Rob Howley has been criticized for not giving more game time to young players, with veteran player Taulupe Faletau saying the onus is on the young players to prove themselves in training.

The Dudley Business Loan Fund, a partnership between Dudley Council and BCRS, offers loans of £10,000 to £50,000 to small and medium-sized businesses in the borough to stimulate local economic growth.

A bill in Arizona's Republican-dominated legislature would make it a crime for transgender individuals to use public facilities that do not match the gender on their birth certificate, punishable by up to six months in prison.
Two men, 19 and 21, were arrested and charged with shining a light at a helicopter in flight while it searched for a missing person in the Northwood area.
Strictly Come Dancing star Gorka Marquez was attacked by a gang of youths while walking to a nightclub in Blackpool, leaving him with chipped teeth that required dental surgery.
A UK primary school apologized after telling 4-11 year olds they would be sent to a refugee camp, sparking concern and stress among parents and children.
A 25-year-old man was sentenced to four years in prison for assaulting a 67-year-old man with disabilities, who was knocked to the ground and robbed outside his home in Gateshead.

Thousands of Haitian migrants are arriving in Quebec, Canada, seeking asylum, with many fleeing US deportation threats, despite Canada's efforts to counter misinformation and deter irregular border crossings.

A study found that pediatricians in England and Wales lack knowledge on identifying underweight children and serious complications, despite having experience with eating disorders, highlighting a need for improved training.

China's Communist Party has announced that couples will be allowed to have two children, ending the decades-long one-child policy aimed at controlling population growth and addressing an aging population.

The Paris Agreement, aimed at limiting global temperature rise to 2°C above pre-industrial levels, comes into force, with governments committing to move away from fossil fuels and review progress every five years.
England's top-ranked Test bowler James Anderson is set to miss the next two County Championship games due to a stress fracture in his right shoulder blade sustained during the Sri Lanka series.
Julian Cuddihy, 43, was found guilty of murdering his parents at their home in County Donegal in 2014 and was sent to a mental hospital for assessment and treatment.
The English football league saw several matches take place, with notable results including Brighton's 1-0 win over Huddersfield and Preston's 3-0 thrashing of Cardiff.

President Trump and his administration disputed crowd size estimates, with Trump claiming the largest audience ever, while photographic evidence and other sources suggested a smaller turnout at his inauguration.

Ukrainians are flocking to Russian-annexed Crimea for summer holidays, despite heightened tensions and claims of sabotage attacks, with many seemingly unaffected by the political rhetoric and military drills.
British Gas and EDF Energy have announced 5.1% and 5% price reductions for standard domestic gas tariffs, respectively, following a 57% drop in wholesale gas prices since last year.

Beijing's severe smog, caused by coal emissions and industrial gases, has engulfed the city, forcing flights to be delayed and visibility to drop to just 50m, despite government efforts to curb pollution.

The Renewable Heat Incentive scandal has sparked a crisis in Northern Ireland's government, leading to the collapse of the executive and a potential election that may see major changes to the region's political structure.
A new paper recommends that women and girls be informed about the normal variations in female genitalia and the risks of labiaplasty, a procedure that has seen a fivefold increase in the past decade.
The Brussels terrorist attacks have sparked a wave of anger and division, but the author argues that unity, not isolation, is the key to rebuilding and preventing further violence.
Mansfield 103.2 radio station in the UK has been targeted eight times in a month with pranksters hijacking broadcasts with the song "The Winker's Song" by comedy band Ivor Biggun.

Chile's Communist Party president, Guillermo Teillier, admitted his party approved an armed operation targeting former dictator Augusto Pinochet in 1986, resulting in the deaths of five troops and injuries to 11 others.
El Salvador's Attorney General raided the local branch of Mossack Fonseca, seizing documents and equipment, amid allegations of tax evasion and money laundering through offshore companies.

A fire and explosion occurred at an "explosive materials production unit" near Iran's Parchin military site, killing two workers and causing damage, amid ongoing international tensions over the country's nuclear program.

Oregon launches a pilot program using iPads and portable printers to make voting easier for disabled residents, allowing them to cast ballots with accessibility features such as font size adjustment and audio assistance.

A third of homeless people in Wales reported that health problems contributed to their homelessness, with many facing barriers to accessing healthcare services and struggling with poor physical and mental health.
Sussex seamer Luke Anyon, 32, has announced his retirement from first-class cricket, citing medical advice, after a 9-year career with the team and 199 wickets at an average of 32.38.
Ben Foakes, 22, has been named in the England Lions squad for the UAE tour after an impressive first season at Surrey, helping the team win promotion to Division One.
Brighton & Hove Albion signs Northern Ireland midfielder Oliver Norwood, a former Manchester United trainee, on a three-year deal, adding depth to their midfield options.

European MEPs rejected amendments to internet traffic regulation, allowing "zero rating" agreements and potentially stifle innovation, despite concerns from net neutrality proponents and tech companies.
Astronomers have released a vast dataset from the Gaia space telescope, mapping the position, brightness, and motion of over a billion stars, with millions more to be added in the coming years.
Toshiba may need to write down the value of its US nuclear unit by $6.1 billion due to cost overruns, potentially seeking aid from Japan's Development Bank of Japan.

President Trump defied diplomatic norms by criticizing the US media, his predecessor, and the intelligence community during a press conference in Warsaw, Poland, amid ongoing investigations into Russian election interference.
The 1986 Commonwealth Games in Edinburgh were marred by a boycott by 32 nations, including Bermuda, due to the British government's stance on apartheid-era South Africa.

Mexican actress Kate del Castillo is being investigated for her alleged ties to drug lord Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, with prosecutors seeking to question her about potential money laundering and business dealings.
A multi-vehicle crash near the Cantref Reservoir in Wales involved five vehicles and resulted in casualties being taken to hospital, with the road closed for two hours.
Neymar is challenging Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo as the world's best player, with his impressive goal-scoring form and leadership at Barcelona sparking comparisons to the two superstars.

Charlie Gard, a 11-month-old boy with mitochondrial depletion syndrome, is receiving 24-hour treatment at London's Great Ormond Street hospital, with his parents seeking to continue life support despite doctors' advice to allow him to die with dignity.
The third series of the BBC drama "Broadchurch" premieres with Olivia Colman and David Tennant reprising their roles as detectives investigating a new rape case in the small town of Dorset.

Business leaders and councils in Devon and Cornwall have written to the Environment Agency and Network Rail, urging a solution to recurring flooding at Cowley Bridge, which has caused significant economic disruption.

The UK housing market is expected to slow down in the short-term due to a 3% stamp duty surcharge on new purchases, but long-term price growth is still predicted to reach 25% over the next five years.
Mexican drug lord Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman was recaptured after a year on the run, and actor Sean Penn's interview with him has raised questions about the legality of the encounter.
British astronaut Tim Peake made history by spending six months on the International Space Station, conducting experiments and learning to adapt to life in space.

A team of volunteers, led by artist Vicky Harrison, created a 600-hour embroidered map of the Ashton Court Estate, highlighting local landmarks and points of interest, to promote the restoration of the Ashton Gatehouse.
Calvin Harris has cancelled his performance at the EMAs due to health issues, citing heart problems, and will return home to seek medical treatment.
A powerful storm system brought severe weather to the southern United States, killing one person in Georgia and causing widespread damage and power outages across multiple states.
Eurosibev Lebedev, owner of the London Evening Standard and Independent, launches London Live TV channel, a 24-hour news and entertainment network, and hints at selling his other newspapers.
Five friends from London, aged 18-27, died in a tragic incident at Camber Sands in East Sussex in August, with four of the deaths being investigated in a coroner's inquest.
Northampton Town manager David Wilder is confident his team will win the league title despite recent draws, citing tough upcoming games and rival teams struggling to put together winning streaks.
Rovers and Morecambe played out a 3-3 draw, with both teams scoring three goals each, including penalties, in an entertaining match.
Manchester City dominated the second half but were denied a late penalty and a win, settling for a 0-0 draw with Everton, who rode their luck and earned a confidence-boosting point.

Jorge Mendes, agent of several high-profile footballers, testified in a Spanish court that he never advised his clients on tax matters, amid allegations of tax evasion by his clients, including Radamel Falcao.
Nick Hedges' 1960s and 70s photos of UK families living in run-down homes are being exhibited, highlighting the ongoing struggle for affordable housing and the need for government support.
The Met Office issued a yellow weather warning for icy conditions on untreated surfaces and slippery roads in 17 counties in Wales, effective from Tuesday night to Wednesday morning.
A multi-vehicle accident occurred on the A74(M) northbound in Moffat, injuring three men, with two taken to hospital and one lane remaining closed for debris removal.
Despite making up 54% of students, women comprise only 47% of graduate scheme applicants, but are more likely to be hired once they apply, according to a survey of 170 employers.
Sierra Leonean footballer Alhaji Conteh, 25, has died, despite being dropped from the national team due to poor health, leaving his teammates and coaches mourning his loss.
Raymond McCord, a victim of the Troubles, seeks a judicial review to block the UK's Brexit process, citing concerns it could undermine the Good Friday Agreement and harm victims' rights.
Dumfries and Galloway Council will pay £1.3m towards remedial works at the DG One centre in Dumfries, which shut in 2014 due to various problems, after initially refusing to reveal the amount.
Facebook's stock fell to an all-time low as analysts and investors worry about the company's ability to generate revenue from mobile users, with ad space limited on smaller screens.
Burton Albion secured a 3-0 win over Colchester United, with Lucas Akins scoring a hat-trick, as the U's were relegated from League Two with a disappointing season.
Lancashire Cricket Club has secured promotion to the top tier with two games remaining, with captain Mark Chilton attributing their success to a strong team effort and home advantage at Old Trafford.
Celtic midfielder Callum Armstrong hopes Dundee United can avoid relegation and redeem their professional reputations, despite being 13 points adrift at the bottom of the Scottish Premiership.
World powers and Iran meet in Istanbul for nuclear talks, with Iran assuring its program is peaceful and the US hinting at a "last chance" for diplomacy to work before considering military action.

Stephen Port, a 41-year-old from Barking, faces 29 charges, including murder, rape, and sexual assault, related to allegations he poisoned and killed four people he met online and sexually assaulted eight others.
French investigators confirm that co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed a Germanwings plane in the Alps on March 24, killing all 150 people on board, including 16 students and two teachers.

Manchester United's record-breaking revenue of £500-510m was boosted by sales of its new kit and Champions League matches, with the club's executive vice-chairman citing the "continued strength of our businesses".

Jose Manuel Barroso, former EU chief, criticizes Greece's economic plans, saying they lack experience and are "completely unacceptable" to other countries, urging structural reforms and responsibility for its financial plight.
Organizers of Sydney's Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras parade have declined to invite former Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, citing his support for a national vote on same-sex marriage.
Two men, aged 25 and 52, were arrested and detained after approximately 300 kg of cannabis resin, 8 kg of cannabis herb, and 1 kg of cocaine were discovered at Donaghmede Park in Dublin.
Paris Saint-Germain beat Nancy 1-0 thanks to Edinson Cavani's late penalty, his 37th goal of the season, to maintain their three-point lead at the top of the Ligue 1 table.
Jordan Spieth shot a 12-under-par round to take a three-shot lead at the PGA Tour event, thanks to a strong finish that included three consecutive birdies from the 14th hole.
The Northern Ireland Education Minister has selected three projects to create shared education campuses, with 10 campuses expected to be established over the next five years.

The BBC is planning to relocate from its current premises, with Sirocco site and a site near Ulster University's new campus emerging as early favourites, pending a development site with studio space and parking.
Black African and Caribbean women are less likely to receive breast cancer screening and are diagnosed at a later stage, resulting in poorer outcomes compared to white women in the UK.
Leicester City's Jamie Vardy serves a three-match ban after being sent off for a two-footed challenge, while the team's struggles continue with only four wins in 18 Premier League games.
Three Syrian refugees, including two 18-year-olds, have pleaded not guilty to charges of sexual assault, with a 16-year-old boy also charged, in a case that may raise tensions in Newcastle.
Bastian Schweinsteiger has been recalled to Manchester United's training squad by Jose Mourinho, but it's unclear if he'll be considered for first-team action due to his lack of match practice.
Radovan Krejcir, a Czech fugitive, was arrested in Johannesburg on charges of kidnap and assault, after being accused of links to a violent underworld and surviving multiple assassination attempts.
Pepe, a 34-year-old Portuguese defender, has announced his departure from Real Madrid after 10 years, citing a lack of playing time and a desire to move on to a new challenge.

A woman who was a victim of domestic abuse had her identity and medical history disclosed to a wider audience by Greater Manchester Police, despite her wishes to remain anonymous, resulting in a large payout.
British athlete Katarina Johnson-Thompson aims to qualify for the Olympics with a score of 6,200 points in the heptathlon, currently trailing leader Brianne Theisen-Eaton by 40 points.
A man in his 40s was rescued by Moelfre lifeboat and coastguard after spending over 15 minutes in the water, showing signs of salt water ingestion and hypothermia.

Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe led a ceremony in Hiroshima to mark the 70th anniversary of the atomic bombing, calling for worldwide nuclear disarmament and remembering the devastating effects of the attack.
Biffa, a waste management company, is installing cameras on its trucks to detect people sleeping in bins and prevent accidental deaths, which killed four people last year.
Oscar Pistorius's sentence for killing his girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp was deemed "shockingly lenient" by prosecutors, who have 21 days to appeal to the Supreme Court of Appeal.

The Gobbins coastal path, a 1.5-mile walkway carved into black basalt cliffs, has been restored after decades of decline and is now open to visitors, offering stunning views and a chance to spot wildlife.
Wasps secured a 34-24 win over Bristol, with Christian Wade scoring his 16th try of the season, to restore their five-point lead at the top of the Championship table.

South Sudan earned a crucial point in their 0-0 draw against Sudan, putting them in line to qualify for the quarter-finals of the tournament after their opening 2-0 win over Djibouti.
French rider Sylvain Voeckler won the final stage of the Tour de Yorkshire after beating Team Sky's Nicolas Roche in a sprint finish, taking advantage of Roche's momentary lapse in concentration.
Maidstone United secured a 2-1 win over Torquay United, with Delano Sam-Yorke and Jack Paxman scoring goals to lift the team out of the relegation zone.

Chelsea's Premier League opener was marked by controversy, as Thibaut Courtois was sent off and Eden Hazard was substituted despite not appearing seriously injured, leading to a 2-1 win over Swansea.

A 10-year-old boy, Lennon Toland, was fatally injured and died after being struck by a van in Shettleston, Glasgow, on Monday, with police appealing for witnesses to the accident.
Australian aid worker Kerry Jane Wilson, 60, was kidnapped from her office in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, but has been released and is safe, according to Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop.
Zimbabwe's government plans to lay off 25,000 civil servants and cancel annual bonuses to reduce its wage bill, which currently consumes nearly 97% of its revenue.
Japan secured a 28-18 win over the United States, thanks to tries from Kotaro Matsushima, Yoshikazu Fujita, and Amanaki Mafi, to finish the pool stage with three wins.
Chris Whelpdale, a 29-year-old midfielder, has joined AFC Wimbledon from Stevenage, scoring nine goals in 24 appearances last season, becoming the club's third summer signing.

Henry Ramos Allup, a 72-year-old opposition politician, will lead Venezuela's National Assembly after a landslide victory, promising to act as an autonomous power and counterbalance to President Maduro's executive branch.
Aqsa Mahmood, a 20-year-old woman from Glasgow, traveled to Syria in 2013 to join the Islamic State as a "Jihadi bride" and later encouraged terrorist acts via a Twitter account.

The UK government has not announced a timeline for the construction of eight Type 26 frigates, with negotiations between the government and BAE Systems ongoing and no specific date for the start of construction available.
A multi-vehicle collision occurred on the M4 motorway in Wales, injuring four people, with the westbound carriageway closed for an unknown duration.
Rufus Norris, a 48-year-old director and former actor, has been appointed as the new artistic director of the National Theatre in London, succeeding Sir Nicholas Hytner in 2015.
The Endeavour project has purchased a 59-year-old German harbour ferry for £1 and aims to raise £3m to restore the vessel for summer day trips from Liverpool to Llandudno.

British Olympic boxers Anthony Joshua, Luke Campbell, and others struggle to achieve success in professional boxing, facing challenges such as loneliness, personal turmoil, and corrupt promoters.
A video showcases the unique and varied lunchbox contents typically packed by Japanese children, which often include items such as rice balls, sandwiches, and pickled vegetables.
Ulster's Ian Humphreys, a 33-year-old fly-half, has announced his retirement from professional rugby after a 15-year career, citing his body's signals that it's time to stop.
Liverpool's 17-year-old player Pacheco has made three appearances for the team, which is currently fifth in the WSL One table, while Doncaster Rovers Belles are struggling at the bottom.
Ireland's Ed Joyce top-scored with 35 in a first-class match against Queensland, with the visitors finishing on 155 all out and Queensland replying with 137-5 at stumps.
Cardiff City's first-team coach Paul Trollope has told two underperforming players, Macheda and Le Fondre, they can seek new clubs, citing the need for fresh faces and quality in the squad.
David Haigh, former managing director of GFH Capital, is accused of fraud and is in custody in Dubai, claiming to have "damaging allegations" about the company's financial conduct.

A report claims that training a 16-year-old soldier costs twice as much as training an adult due to longer training and a higher drop-out rate, with the UK being increasingly isolated in its practice of recruiting minors.
Ireland's men's hockey team secured a 4-3 win over France in their opening Pool B match, thanks to goals from Kyle Good, Peter Caruth, Jonathan Bruton, and Shane O'Donoghue.

The Renewable Heat Incentive inquiry, led by Sir Patrick Coghlin, will investigate failings in the scheme, including allegations of political pressure and overspending, without a time limit for completion.
Police responded to a suspicious object report at Butcher Gate, which was later deemed a hoax, and faced disturbances including fireworks and petrol bombs thrown in the Fahan Street area.
The PSNI has warned the public about a parking notice scam, urging people to disregard emails from CPS Enforcement Northern Ltd and not to respond or click on links, as they can infect devices.
Tottenham Hotspur signs 22-year-old Cameroon striker Clinton N'Jie from Ligue 1 side Lyon on a five-year contract, replacing departed striker Roberto Soldado.
Fleetwood Town defeated Oxford United 3-1, with Ashley Eastham and David Ball scoring late goals to secure the win and move the team to third place in the league table.
British police have arrested Altaf Hussain, a powerful Pakistani politician living in exile in London, in a raid on his home, sparking violence and protests in Karachi.
Scientists have analyzed a 200-million-year-old skeleton of a small, plant-eating dinosaur, Heterodontosaurus tucki, using a synchrotron to gain insights into its diet, movement, and behavior.

Peter Rippon, a former Newsnight editor, has been appointed to lead the BBC's Journal of Record, a project to digitize and make available the corporation's 80-year archive of television and radio journalism.
Oxford United's Robert Hall equalized with a 20-yard drive in the 54th minute, cancelling out Oldham's early goal, as the teams drew 1-1 in their League One match.
Chrissie Hynde, the lead singer of The Pretenders, has sparked controversy by saying that women who are sexually assaulted are partly to blame for their own victimization due to their behavior.
Software developer Mark Allison embarks on a 100-day, 3,400-mile run from Lisbon to Istanbul, aiming to raise money for charity while tackling 9,000ft climbs and 15 Tour de France climbs.
A six-month-old baby died after being attacked by a pit bull at her home, and her mother and grandmother are charged with owning a dog that caused the death.

A Missouri jury has awarded $55 million to a 62-year-old woman who claimed Johnson & Johnson's talc-based powder products caused her ovarian cancer, despite the company's insistence on the products' safety.

The Progressive Unionist Party's election manifesto criticizes the DUP and Sinn Féin for using "fear tactics" and not addressing real issues, instead promoting a "Country Before Party" agenda.

A fire at the Hampton by Hilton Hotel in Corby, Northamptonshire, required eight engines and 40 firefighters to respond, with four people treated for smoke inhalation.
Wayne Rooney equaled Sir Bobby Charlton's record for Manchester United by scoring the first goal in a FA Cup tie against Reading, with 250 goals in 806 appearances.

Mario Balotelli, a 26-year-old Italian striker, scored 15 goals for Nice in the French Ligue 1 last season, following a free transfer from Liverpool in 2016.

English golfer Tyrrell Hatton earned £235,557 as Scottish Open runner-up and heads to the US PGA in New Jersey, where he aims to build on his recent form and Ryder Cup prospects.

Gilbert Corette, 45, was sentenced to a hospital order with no time limit after admitting to the manslaughter of his mother and causing harm to his sister, citing diminished responsibility due to depression and Asperger's syndrome.
Alistair McGeady has rejoined Sunderland, reuniting with manager Simon Grayson, after previously playing for him at Preston North End and having stints at Everton and Spartak Moscow.

The National Deep Rummage Team searches commercial vessels entering UK waters to detect and intercept illegal drugs, using specialized training and tactics to overcome the challenges of searching vast and hostile environments.
Andy Goode scored 33 points, including a try and eight penalties, in Wasps' 41-16 win over London Irish in front of a record Premiership crowd of 28,254 at the Ricoh Arena.

The British gymnastics team won the silver medal at the European Championships, finishing just behind Russia and ahead of France, despite four falls on beam and uneven bars.
Leicester Tigers edged Bristol 15-14 in a physical match, with Manu Tuilagi returning from injury and Ellis Genge scoring a try, earning a vital win and keeping them within a point of third place.

A police officer testified that her former supervisor, Det Sgt Andrew Mottau, left a black monkey toy on her desk, making her feel ridiculed and harassed, and made racist remarks during a four-day misconduct hearing.
The Birmingham St. Patrick's Day parade, featuring floats, pipe bands, and dancers, celebrates Irish heritage with over 80,000 attendees, marking the third largest parade in the world.
A showcase of stunning photographs captures the beauty and diversity of African cultures and landscapes from around the continent and beyond.

The Trussell Trust reported a 20% increase in people using its food banks in the UK, with 39,174 people receiving emergency food aid in six months, citing benefit delays, low income, and changes as common reasons.

The British Medical Association recommends taxing sugary drinks to reduce consumption and subsidize fresh fruit and vegetables to combat the estimated 70,000 premature deaths caused by poor diets each year.
Worcester City FC will leave their historic St George's Lane ground for a temporary home at Kidderminster Harriers' Aggborough Stadium, but hopes to return to the city in the long term.

Scientists have discovered fossils of a 700,000-year-old human ancestor on the Indonesian island of Flores, which suggests that the "Hobbit" species may have shrunk from a normal-sized species within a remarkably short period.
A 34-year-old woman from Bradford was sentenced to prison for attempting to abduct her children to take them to Raqqa, Syria, to live under Islamic State control.

The FTSE 100 fell 5.51 points to 6,815.28, led by declines in mining shares due to a stronger US dollar, while banking shares and the pound against the euro rose.

Canine distemper virus, a highly infectious and deadly disease, is threatening the survival of the endangered Amur tiger population, with conservation efforts focusing on identifying the reservoir and developing a vaccination program.

Heavy rainfall in Argentina's Entre Rios province and neighboring Paraguay and Uruguay has caused widespread flooding, affecting thousands of people, with the worst-hit areas being Concordia and surrounding towns.
Joseph Tsang, a 31-year-old IT worker, was convicted in absentia of multiple sexual offenses, including rape and sexual assault, and is now facing extradition from Hong Kong to the UK for sentencing.
Rick Astley's album "50" reached number one in the UK, earning him his first chart-topper in nearly 30 years, and is now a nominee for the BBC Radio 2 album of the year award.

Willard Wigan, a micro-sculptor, is exhibiting his intricate works, including tiny sculptures of famous figures and characters, at the Library of Birmingham, with proceeds supporting literacy programs.
Six councils in north-west England granted or renewed permits to over 300 convicted drivers, including sex offenders, despite guidelines recommending refusal, sparking concerns over public safety.

An internal investigation at Glasgow City Council's land and environmental services department is underway, examining allegations of cronyism and procurement irregularities, with police also involved in the inquiry.
Bert Williams, a 71-year-old angler from Wirral, caught a 93lb cod off Norway, a record-breaking catch for a British angler and the largest for a disabled angler.
Labour MP Peter Kyle urges the government to take action to increase the number of armed police in Sussex, citing a 43% increase in requests for help from neighboring forces.

Ken Loach's film I, Daniel Blake exposes the UK's welfare system, highlighting the struggles of a 59-year-old man who is deemed fit for work despite having a heart condition and must choose between going hungry or dropping out of the system.
Prince's estate is being contested by 45 claimants, including a prisoner claiming to be his son, with the singer's sister and half-siblings waiting to inherit his $200m fortune.
Stephen Hendry, a seven-time world snooker champion, has announced his retirement from professional snooker, citing a lack of enjoyment and pressure from a demanding schedule.
A former employee brandished a knife and took a woman hostage at a restaurant in Australia, but was arrested after police negotiations and was taken to hospital for checks.
A German aid worker kidnapped in a Kabul neighborhood was released, with the GIZ organization describing her condition as "good, considering the circumstances" and her as "very relieved and happy".
Three years after Russia's annexation of Crimea, the region remains in a state of flux, with residents struggling to adapt to new circumstances and a population divided in their loyalties.

A man's homemade hut in a woodland area was demolished by the Woodland Trust, which owns the land, after he was arrested for obstructing officials and eventually forced to leave and seek alternative accommodation.
A man was fatally injured in a collision on the A466 Wye Valley Link Road in Chepstow, Wales, and pronounced dead at the scene, with the road remaining closed for several hours.
M Squared Lasers, a Scottish company, has secured £3.25m in funding from Barclays and BGF to support its growth plans, with a focus on expanding its export business and quantum technologies.

Militants led by ISIS have taken control of parts of Falluja and Ramadi, displacing over 50,000 families, with many fleeing to refugee camps and living in dire conditions with limited access to basic necessities.
The 2016 Summer Olympics in Brazil kicked off with a spectacular opening ceremony featuring fireworks, a parade of nations, and the lighting of the Olympic torch.
Police are investigating vandalism and disorder at a Rangers-Celtic game, seeking video footage and witness statements after toilets were damaged and fans' behavior sparked concern.
Dozens of birds were found dead and arranged in a line along a road in Devon, with police seeking witnesses and pigeon fanciers to help investigate the cause of their deaths.
Ivory Coast President Alassane Ouattara has announced that his supporters will not be prosecuted for war crimes by the International Criminal Court, citing the country's operational justice system.
The Afrobasket 2015 basketball tournament is being held in Tunis, Tunisia, with Egypt and Gabon opening the event, and defending champions Angola favored to win the title.
Eliza Szonert, an Australian actress, was allowed to leave Malaysia with her son without charge after a custody dispute with businessman Ashley Crick, with whom she had a disagreement over passports.
Wavegarden Scotland plans to transform a quarry near Edinburgh into a massive lake with wave-generating technology, creating over 80 jobs and positioning Scotland as a leading surfing destination.
The match between Notts County and Morecambe was abandoned due to a waterlogged pitch after just 45 minutes, with the score 0-0 at halftime.
Two British soldiers, L/Cpl David Gwilt and rifleman Dale Harris, died in a car crash in Northern Ireland in 2014 after failing to stop at a junction, resulting in a collision with a tractor.
Inmarsat has ordered two new spacecraft, the Inmarsat-6 series, from Airbus at a cost of 550m euros, to update its services in the L-band and Ka-band radio spectrum.
South African cricketer Wayne Parnell will leave Glamorgan after Sunday's T20 match to join the South African team in Bangladesh, but hopes to return to the Welsh county in the future.
Mark Beaumont, a 33-year-old adventurer who holds the record for cycling around the world, was elected unopposed as the new rector of the University of Dundee.

A Scottish commission has urged the government to take action to address socioeconomic inequalities in university admissions, citing a "undeniable case for change" to ensure equal access to higher education.
Scotland's economy grew by 0.7% in the second quarter, driven by services and finance, but still lags behind the UK's 2.1% growth rate over the past year.

South Africa's Hashim De Kock scored an unbeaten 129 as his team made 475, while England's Alastair Cook and Joe Root shared an unbroken 60-run partnership at the close of play.
Mark Durkan, the SDLP's MP for Foyle, lost his seat to Sinn Féin's Elisha McCallion by 169 votes, ending the party's 34-year hold on the constituency.
The Ministry of Justice is selling HMP Shrewsbury, a Grade II listed building, and inviting private companies to bid on its redevelopment, potentially into flats or a hotel.
The UK's Ministry of Defence has announced that a law firm, Public Interest Lawyers (PIL), will cease operation at the end of August due to breach of contractual requirements.

Oldham Council investigated allegations of extremism at Clarksfield Primary School, concluding no concerns were found, while a counter-extremism official raised concerns about two other schools in the area.

Nine Welsh councils have reduced their respite care budgets, sparking concerns that vulnerable groups may be denied essential support, with some families already struggling to access limited services.
Lloyd Janse, a former Netherlands Under-21 international, has joined Leyton Orient on an undisclosed deal, adding depth to the club's defense and midfield options.
A former aide testified in federal court that New Jersey Governor Chris Christie was told about a political revenge plot to block traffic lanes at a 9/11 memorial service in 2013.
The British Board of Film Classification has given the film "Paddington" a PG certificate due to "mild innuendo" and some scenes that may be considered inappropriate for young viewers.
Bristol Rugby has signed two players, Tavare and Van Buuren, to long-term contracts, with Van Buuren set to stay until the end of the 2018 season.

The Care Quality Commission has charged Royal Hampshire County Hospital's Melbury Lodge with failing to provide safe care and treatment to a patient who sustained serious injuries from a fall in 2015.
Four schools in Moray, Scotland will undergo a £10m refurbishment, funded by a government grant and the council, to upgrade roofs, windows, toilets, and heating and electrical systems.

The Linda Norgrove Foundation supports the Ascend project, which teaches mountaineering skills to young Afghan women, empowering them and changing their lives, in memory of Linda Norgrove, who was killed in a rescue attempt.
Viola Beach, a four-piece British band, died in a car crash in Sweden after their gig, with the driver, manager Craig Tarry, losing control of the vehicle as a bridge was being raised.
The UK government has announced a 3% increase in the minimum wage, benefiting a million workers, with rates rising to £5.13 for 18-20-year-olds and £2.73 for apprentices.

Labour's Gareth Snell wins the Stoke Central by-election, but with the lowest turnout in the constituency's history and a narrow margin, sparking concerns about the party's connection with the local community.
Rangers' under-20 coach Graeme Murty earned his first Premiership win with a 3-2 victory over St Johnstone, with midfielder Jonny Hyndman scoring the late winner and praising Murty's efforts.
Facebook's Trending Topics section has been accused of suppressing conservative news and promoting liberal stories, with some staff allegedly editing the section to reflect their own biases.
The Strathspey Steam Railway will recreate a 1863 train journey between Aviemore and Broomhill on August 3, with passengers encouraged to wear Victorian attire and travel free on a steam locomotive.
A French court granted an eviction order to the theatre's owners due to technical grounds, allowing the comedian to stay pending appeal, despite his controversial history and past convictions.

British astronaut Major Tim Peake, set to fly to the International Space Station in December, spoke to a London school, expressing pride in representing the UK and highlighting the rigorous training he's undergone.
BP has lost its appeal to the US Supreme Court, which means it must continue making payments to victims of the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill without a cap on damages.
A woman was forced into a dark-coloured car and attacked on the Sydenham Bypass, but managed to escape, with the suspect described as a man in his 30s wearing a dark hooded top.
HS2 Ltd has delayed the construction of Euston station's expansion to 2033, citing easier management and reduced impact on daily train capacity, with a revised budget of £2.25 billion.
Brazil advanced to the Olympic semi-finals with a 2-0 win over Honduras, thanks to goals from Neymar and Luan, securing their third consecutive appearance in the last four.

Deutsche Bank has announced it will repurchase €3bn of euro-denominated bonds and $2bn of dollar-denominated bonds, signaling the bank's financial robustness and alleviating concerns about its capital.
Camden Council approved a £41m plan to ban cars from Tottenham Court Road in central London, except for buses, bicycles, and local access, citing safety and business benefits.
UK Prime Minister David Cameron refuses to participate in televised debates with other party leaders unless the Green Party is included, sparking a row over the format of the debates.
A train derailed in Leicestershire after a tipper truck struck a footbridge, injuring the driver and causing damage, due to a lack of proper safety assessment and planning at the construction site.
Physicist Peter Higgs, 84, has been awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics for his theory of the Higgs boson, a fundamental particle that explains how matter gets its mass.
Chiefs' key player Julian Salvi suffered a serious injury during the Champions Cup match against Ulster and will require surgery, leaving a significant void in the team.
The Lionesses' third-place finish in the World Cup marks the team's most successful finish ever, with coach Mark Sampson credited for bringing a "togetherness" and "family atmosphere" to the team.
Scotland's women's national team will compete in their first major tournament, Euro 2017, with a challenging group schedule featuring England, Spain, and Portugal.
A leaked NHS report reveals a £400-450m funding gap and suggests sweeping changes, including hospital centralization and service closures, are needed to break even by 2017.
Gramercy, a Connecticut-based hedge fund, purchased defaulted Peruvian bonds at a discount and is threatening to sue the country under a US-Peruvian trade deal to recover its investment.
Natacha Bouchart, a French politician, told MPs that most migrants in Calais see the UK as a "soft touch" for benefits and work, with less than 10% seeking asylum in France.
George Kay, 35, was charged with assault, unlawful possession of a stun gun, and possessing a bladed article, including a hunting knife found in his wardrobe.
A 29-year-old golfer birdied three of the last four holes to finish on 20 under par, narrowly missing the top spot in a closely contested tournament.
Shelly Provan joins Notts County Women's team from Reading, bringing experience and a new attacking option on the left-hand side, ahead of the Spring Series in the Women's Super League.
Mick Schumacher, son of F1 legend Michael Schumacher, will drive a 1994 Benetton car in a demonstration lap, marking his first public appearance since his father's serious skiing accident in 2013.
Sinn Féin has proposed an individual to chair the new talks process to resolve the stalemate in Northern Ireland, following the failure to form a power-sharing executive.
Syrian government forces are on the brink of capturing the city of Aleppo, with rebels warning of "real massacres" and civilians trapped in the besieged enclave.

The Police Federation of Northern Ireland's chairman, Mark Lindsay, expressed low confidence in the office of the ombudsman, citing a lack of trust and concerns over investigations and budget cuts affecting the PSNI.
Police are investigating the murder of 17-year-old Megan Bannister, whose body was found in a car after a crash, with two men, 27 and 28, still being questioned on suspicion of murder.
The reburial cortege of Richard III will pass through Leicestershire and Leicester on March 22, retracing the route he took in 1485, from Fenn Lane to the city centre.
Ed "Stewpot" Stewart, a beloved British radio DJ and presenter, has died at the age of unknown, leaving behind a legacy of iconic shows and a lifetime of memories.

Natalie Bennett, the former leader of the UK's Green Party, rose to prominence in just six years, becoming a prominent figure in British politics despite struggling to articulate her party's message in soundbites.
Piers Linney, a digital entrepreneur and former investment banker, joins the BBC's Dragons' Den as a new dragon, bringing expertise in the information economy and digital industry.
Kent councils are owed thousands of pounds in unpaid fines from foreign drivers, with some councils using a private company to recover the debt, while others have written off unpaid fines.

Wales' former striker Ian Rush believes the team's low seeding and strong qualifying record will make them an attractive opponent for other nations, increasing their chances of advancing in the tournament.

The Welsh Rugby Union is seeking to take over Newport Gwent Dragons and Rodney Parade, planning to install a 4G surface, but may reconsider if Newport County avoids relegation and can maintain a grass pitch.
British motorcycle rider Bradley Kent secured second place in the 2022 Moto3 World Championship after finishing ninth in the final race in Spain, with Miguel Oliveira winning the title.

A Russian Mi-8 helicopter carrying humanitarian aid to Aleppo was shot down by rebels in northern Idlib province, killing five people, in the worst single loss of life for Russia in Syria since its intervention.
John Cantlie, a British journalist, appears in a new ISIS video, ridiculing US efforts to destroy the group, in his first footage in over a year.
Australian animal welfare groups are calling for a ban on live cattle exports to Egypt after releasing footage showing "horrific" treatment of Australian cattle in Egyptian abattoirs.
Newcastle United and Birmingham City drew 1-1 in their FA Cup replay, with Newcastle's Matt Ritchie scoring the winning penalty in the second half.
Hull FC came from behind to defeat Warrington 12-10 in the Challenge Cup final, securing a late win and sending a strong message ahead of the Super League play-off semi-finals.
Bury and Walsall drew 3-3, with James Vaughan and Reece Brown scoring for Bury, and Erhun Oztumer and Jason McCarthy scoring twice for Walsall.
Katty Kay answers questions from the public on the 2012 US presidential election, discussing topics such as the outcome, Obama's second term, and the future of the Republican Party.
A 14-year-old boy was left in a coma after his drink was spiked with MDMA, and his aunt is sharing his photo to raise awareness about the dangers of drug use.
A 30cm-diameter well in Baoding, Hebei province, collapsed, trapping a 6-year-old boy who fell 40m down, with rescuers using excavators and dump trucks to try to retrieve him.
Tajikistan is Central Asia's poorest nation, with a fragile economy and a history of civil war, poverty, and dependence on foreign aid, particularly from Russia and China.
A fire broke out at a refugee center in Duesseldorf, Germany, prompting evacuations and a response from 70 firefighters, with smoke drifting towards the nearby airport.
Blanca Katsura, a Peruvian woman of Japanese descent, recounts her family's experience being forcibly deported to the US during World War II and their subsequent internment in a camp.

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) scrapped a planned review into bank scandals, citing duplication of work by other bodies and a lack of value in the findings, despite facing criticism over its independence.

The Sweden Democrats, a right-wing party with a history of scandals, has won 49 seats in Sweden's parliament, despite controversies over racism and anti-immigrant comments, thanks to leader Jimmie Akesson's charisma and messaging.
Hills Quarry Products has submitted a plan to extract 2.5 million tonnes of earth over 10 years from a site near Clifton Hampden, sparking concerns over health, wellbeing, and increased traffic.
