A business, Three Wise Monkeys Climbing, aims to convert a church into a climbing centre, having already raised £30,000 in 23 days through a crowdfunding appeal.

Two 17-year-old and 18-year-old students, Alexandria Hollinghurst and Brandon Goode, were found dead in Florida after shooting and killing a police officer, with notes suggesting suicide, but an investigation is ongoing.
The Coseley School in Dudley, England, is facing closure due to declining enrollment and poor academic performance, with a consultation period set to run until April 5.

Three pro-EU MPs argue that the UK's exit from the single market will create "losers" as almost all sectors are linked to the EU, and that cherry-picking trade agreements is impractical and may create "losers".
A 6.8-magnitude earthquake struck Myanmar, causing a bridge to collapse and at least six deaths, with reports of widespread damage and injuries across the country.
The Leeds Rhinos lost to the North Queensland Cowboys in the World Club Challenge, with the Rhinos' coach, McDermott, citing the need for the competition to continue to improve the team.
A new study found that while education is not a direct protector against dementia, it helps individuals cope with brain changes associated with the condition, reducing the risk of dementia symptoms.
A man, identified as Daniel Morris, was killed in a crash on the Belfast Road between Fivemiletown and Brookborough, County Tyrone, on Friday morning.
Northern Ireland's Residential Property Price Index rose 7% in 2014, exceeding expectations, driven by strong economic recovery and low supply, but growth is expected to slow in 2015.

Hong Kong's economic integration with mainland China has brought success as a global financial center, but has also created problems, including widening wealth gaps, corruption, and distrust of the Chinese government.
Mark Selby won the World Snooker Championship, coming back from 10-4 down to defeat John Higgins 18-15 and claim his third world title.
Vietnam's government has granted amnesty to thousands of prisoners, including those convicted of murder and drug-related crimes, but political prisoners are unlikely to be released.
Boko Haram militants attacked the village of Dalori, killing at least 65 people and leaving many more injured, with witnesses describing hours of shooting and burning of homes and livestock.

A new CGI animated mini-series adaptation of Richard Adams' classic novel "Watership Down" is being produced by the BBC and Netflix, featuring a star-studded voice cast and a focus on female characters.

British expats in Spain, numbering between 300,000 and 700,000, are concerned about the potential impact of a UK exit from the EU on their rights, including healthcare and work, if the country votes to leave.

Oxford City Council has approved BMW's plans to expand on its Cowley site, relocating leisure facilities, including Oxford United's training ground and Oxford Cricket Club, to make way for new facilities.

The 160-year-old Crumlin Road Courthouse in Belfast is being considered for restoration and conversion into a tourist attraction, with options ranging from renovation to mothballing parts of the building.
A man was injured in an attack on Shakespeare Street in the early hours of Monday morning, with police searching for two suspects in connection with the incident.
Two people were arrested and a significant amount of dangerous materials, including ammunition and explosives, were seized during a search of two properties in Northern Ireland.
Fleetwood Town dominated the match, scoring three goals, including two by David Ball, to defeat Northampton Town 3-0 in their League One encounter.

The UK's National Offender Management Service has admitted that it has been underreporting overcrowding in prisons, with two prisoners sharing a cell designed for one person, and has vowed to improve data accuracy.
R&B Distillers is transforming a derelict Victorian hotel on the Isle of Raasay into a distillery and visitor center, with production of its first whisky expected to begin in April 2024.
China celebrated the first day of the Year of the Monkey with a massive fireworks display in Beijing, marking the start of a festive period of feasting, temple visits, and family gatherings.

Researchers at Edinburgh University's Royal (Dick) School of Veterinary Studies are studying the link between vitamin D levels and recovery in dogs after surgery, exploring its potential impact on inflammation and overall health outcomes.
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is promoting yoga as a way to improve health and set a Guinness World Record, with plans to gather 35,000 people for a mass yoga session in Delhi.
Koukash's rugby league club was fined and docked points for salary cap breaches, leading him to threaten a vote of no confidence in the RFL's leadership and criticize the sport's financial state.
Former Northern Ireland MLA and MP Peter Wilson reflects on his time in politics, including a humorous exchange with Gerry Adams over planting a GAA tree in the Stormont grounds.
The Scottish SPCA is rehoming two large lizards, Pintosh and Babysha, separately due to their size and aggression towards each other, seeking experienced iguana owners with suitable housing.
Societe Generale reported a 40% increase in second-quarter net income, beating estimates, and plans to boost its capital buffer and cut costs by €1.75bn by 2017.

The IPCC releases its new climate change report, featuring updated data and projections, amidst concerns over past errors and criticism from climate sceptics, with a focus on sea level rise and Arctic ice melting.
Maydown Precision Engineering in Londonderry, acquired by Schivo Group, considers cutting 10-15 jobs, prompting union concerns and accusations of breaching recognition agreement.
Liverpool Ladies midfielder Sophie Zelem leaves the club after four years, citing a desire for a new challenge after helping the team win two consecutive Women's Super League titles.

Clashes broke out between players and fans at a Serbia-Albania soccer match in Belgrade after a drone flew a political flag into the stadium, prompting Uefa to charge both teams' FAs with various offenses.
Fourteen men, from England and Northern Ireland, were convicted of stealing £57m worth of Chinese jade and rhino horn from several museums and auction houses between 2011 and 2012.
Chinese swimmer Fu Yuanhui became a social media sensation by openly discussing her period and its impact on her performance, sparking a conversation about menstruation and tampon use in China.
Police pursued a Volkswagen Golf that sped through several towns in Northern Ireland at over 100mph before crashing and abandoning the vehicle, with occupants fleeing the scene.
The search is on for volunteers to form local action groups in rural areas of Denbighshire, Flintshire, and Wrexham to target funding and regeneration efforts.
Bingham won his first ranking title since 2015 by defeating Trump 9-8 in the World Snooker Championship, coming back from 4-0 down to claim the victory.
Cavan's Farrelly will officiate the Dr McKenna Cup match between Fermanagh and St Mary's, having made history as the first female to referee an inter-county game in the Ulster minor Championship.

Alan Dawson, a 64-year-old man from Urmston, was convicted of indecent assault and rape for abusing four girls between the 1960s and 1980s at his home and theirs, gaining their trust through his position at a local church.
A fire broke out at a furniture business in Stonebridge, Milton Keynes, but was quickly contained by fire crews, with no injuries reported.
Elland Bridge in Elland partially collapsed due to flooding, and a temporary footbridge has been installed, with a new bridge not expected to be operational until at least December 2016.
Leinster defeated the Dragons 40-21, scoring 6 tries to 3, to move to the top of the table, leapfrogging Munster after a strong second half performance.
Former Cardiff City manager Russell Slade has been appointed Charlton Athletic's new boss, signing a three-year deal after leaving Cardiff after just 28 days to replace manager Paul Trollope.
The BBC is giving one million Micro Bits to UK secondary school pupils to encourage coding and digital skills, part of a wider effort to address the UK's growing digital skills shortage.
Thousands of protesters clashed with police in Kiev over a new law granting official status to the Russian language, sparking concerns about Ukrainian identity and national unity.
Gary Fung, founder of Isohunt, has agreed to pay $50 million in damages and legal costs to Music Canada after shutting down the site in 2013, which linked to pirated content.
Manar, a Syrian refugee, fled her war-torn homeland with her family, describing the trauma of living in a camp and the joy of starting anew in Bradford, UK.
The UK Conservative Party is considering a plan to raise the inheritance tax threshold for family homes to £350,000, benefiting over 20,000 estates by 2020, according to leaked Treasury documents.
Redwan El-Ghaidouni, 38, was shot eight times in his car in Uxbridge, London, and police have arrested four people on suspicion of conspiracy to murder, including a 36-year-old man released on bail.

Mark Ronson's song "Uptown Funk", featuring Bruno Mars, was released earlier than planned after its performance on the X Factor, capitalizing on its popularity and competition with other holiday singles.
Morecambe re-signs midfielder Kevin Thompson, who helped the team win promotion to the Football League in 2007, and midfielder Michael Rose on one-year deals.
Chinese Ambassador Liu Xiaoming says President Xi Jinping's state visit will focus on cooperation and partnership between the UK and China, downplaying the importance of human rights discussions.
A severe fire broke out at a metal recycling yard in Wolverhampton, with six fire engines responding and the blaze being brought under control by 03:30.

Mauritania finished second in their African Nations Cup group, missing a spot in the tournament, but coach Amara Traore is proud of the team's progress and potential despite being considered a "lightweight" in African football.
A whistleblower who spoke out against a government corruption scandal is now living in exile in the US, revealing the personal cost of his decision to speak out.
Hamilton Academical won 1-0 against Ross County, with Dougie Imrie scoring the only goal from close range in the 30th minute, assisted by Darian MacKinnon.

Arsenal's defense is under scrutiny, with Laurent Koscielny's return to the lineup crucial to improve their chances against Leicester City, who are seeking to bounce back from a disappointing loss to Hull.
Ruby Walsh announced his retirement after riding Cantlow to victory in the Irish Grand National, with Enda Bolger's stable star winning the prestigious race.
Irish boxer Katie Taylor remained unbeaten in her professional career, defeating Bulgarian Koleva by knocking her down in the seventh round in Manchester.
Alistair Thompson, 43, was sentenced to prison for assaulting 44-year-old Alexander Powell, leaving him needing surgery, with the judge citing Thompson's lack of remorse and chronic alcohol problem.

Leicestershire County Council is considering closing Snibston Discovery Museum to save £9.4m over 25 years, but a consultant claims the plan is flawed and would actually cost more to implement than the proposed savings.
Charlton Athletic defeated Scunthorpe United 3-1 in an FA Cup match, with Ademola Lookman scoring a sublime left-footed strike and Johnnie Jackson and Tom Hopper also finding the net.
The US Office of Naval Research is developing a low-cost, autonomous drone system called Locust, capable of flying in swarms and being launched from ships, aircraft, or land vehicles.
Wind farms in Scotland generated 699,684MWh of electricity in April, enough to power 79% of Scottish households, a 15% increase from the same period last year.
Nathan Smith and substitute Iffy Allen scored for Torquay United, securing a 2-0 win and moving the team level on points with Welling in the National League table.
South African President Jacob Zuma faces growing pressure to resign, with the Congress of South African Trade Unions and anti-apartheid veterans calling for his removal following a cabinet reshuffle.
A Kentucky man is suing the state over his rejected personalized license plate, "IM GOD," arguing it's a form of free speech protected by the First Amendment.
Pakistan was eliminated from the T20 World Cup after losing to Australia, citing a decline in the team's performance and lack of international cricket at home since 2009.

The UK Government-owned Green Investment Bank has invested £668m in clean energy projects, including offshore wind farms, and expects to deliver a 8% annual return to taxpayers once the projects are completed.

A Libyan-chartered ship carrying aid and activists was intercepted by Israeli naval ships and forced to head to Egypt, rather than Gaza, after being surrounded and given an ultimatum to change course.
The pilot of the jet that crashed at the Shoreham Air Show in 2015, killing 11 people, has been re-interviewed by police as part of a manslaughter investigation.

The US Mint has released a 24-carat gold coin commemorating its 225th anniversary, featuring Liberty with a crown of stars and a toga-like dress, with plans for future coins depicting women from ethnic minorities.
Manchester City has signed Brazilian international Danilo, a versatile defender and midfielder, on a five-year deal, taking their summer spending to almost £150m.
Actor Jack O'Connell, a Derby County fan, joins Lawro to predict Premier League fixtures, sharing his opinions on upcoming matches and sharing fond memories of the Rams' past.
Nemanja Vidic, a former Manchester United and Inter Milan defender, has announced his retirement from professional football due to injuries, citing a toll on his body from the past few years.

Jonathan Green, a former sales manager at Graham Builders Merchants in Dundee, embezzled £73,386 from the company over a year, using the money to settle personal debts and repaying the remainder from his pension fund.
Sunderland striker Jermain Defoe reflects on his bond with six-year-old Bradley Lowery, who has a terminal illness and is receiving palliative care, saying it was the highlight of his season.
Merle Haggard, a country music legend, rose to fame with his distinctive voice and songwriting, influencing a generation of singers and achieving 95 country hits, including 38 number ones.
Scholars used a replica of Stonehenge in the US to study its acoustic properties, finding that it reacted to sound in a way that would have been noticeable to Neolithic people.
Felix, a 21-year-old midfielder, has joined Boston United from St Neots Town, making 32 appearances and scoring five goals for the National League North club last season.
Eighteen-year-old midfielder Lewis Vieira has signed a new contract with the club and has been called up to the England Under-20 squad for the Toulon Tournament.
Melania Trump defended her husband Donald Trump, saying his lewd comments were "boy talk" and he was "egged on" by Billy Bush, and that the scandal was orchestrated to hurt his candidacy.

Despite government efforts to relocate and control them, traditional Tibetan nomadic communities in China's Sichuan province continue to maintain their way of life, albeit under pressure from tourism and development.

The historic Banbury North signal box in Oxfordshire, dating back to 1901, was demolished overnight, despite efforts to save it, as part of Network Rail's plan to replace over 800 signal boxes with 12 Regional Operating Centres.

The Scottish Business Resilience Centre urges businesses to prioritize software updates and cybersecurity measures to prevent attacks like WannaCry, which affected GP surgeries and other primary care centers.

England has announced a 12-man squad for the upcoming four-Test series, with Yorkshire's Gary Ballance, Toby Roland-Jones, and Mark Wood included, and Keaton Jennings and Alastair Cook set to open the batting.

A BBC-ORB International poll found that 66% of Iraqis and 57% of Syrians believe their country is heading in the wrong direction, with many also opposing coalition air strikes and viewing Islamic State as a negative influence.
Developers are exploring a plan to build up to 14 wind turbines on a site in Scotland, which could generate 44.8MW of energy over 25 years.
Three men from Walsall, aged 35 and 45, are due to appear in court on charges of engaging in sexual activity with a child, inciting a child to engage in such activity, and taking indecent images.

The Grade II listed Tramsheds building in Cardiff's Grangetown area has received offers and the council seeks a "viable and sustainable solution" for the site, including potential community uses and arts spaces.
Sevilla thrashed Malaga 4-1 in La Liga, with Luciano Vietto and Wissam Ben Yedder scoring two goals each, and Vitolo adding another, to close the gap on leaders Real Madrid.

The UK's tax and benefit changes, including a higher personal income tax allowance, are set to benefit 94% of working households, according to the Conservatives, while Labour claims average families are £1,100 worse off since 2010.
Novak Djokovic's coach, Richard Krajicek, released Nick Kyrgios from his contract to allow him to participate in the NBA All-Star game in New Orleans.
Michael Sheill, a private clinic owner, was found to be performing botox consultations without a registered practitioner present, potentially breaching medical rules and putting patients at risk.
Cardiff City Football Club is hosting a charity match to honor the memory of three teenagers, including Corey Price, who died in a car crash, with proceeds going towards memorial benches.

The EIS union's general secretary, Larry Flanagan, criticized politicians and journalists for exaggerating education problems and called for a more balanced approach, while also backing a motion for a backdated pay rise for teachers.

A 56-year-old man was rescued from St Cyrus beach after getting into difficulties, suffering suspected rib injuries, and was airlifted to Aberdeen Royal Infirmary with a non-life-threatening condition.

The Trump campaign's meeting with a Russian lawyer in June 2016, facilitated by Donald Trump Jr., raises questions about potential collusion and whether the campaign sought damaging information on Hillary Clinton from Russia.

Federal authorities raided several hotels and birth tourism agencies in the US, targeting companies suspected of engaging in visa fraud and illegal activities, including falsifying records and documents.
A woman was caught on CCTV driving golf buggies around a course in Eastbourne, Sussex, with her dog, causing £1,000 worth of damage, before returning the vehicles and charging them.
A man was attacked with a substance at a fish and chip shop in Whitstable, Kent, leaving him with facial injuries and no arrests have been made.
South African coach Stuart Baxter has named a 25-man squad for the Africa Cup of Nations qualifier against Nigeria, featuring a mix of domestic and European-based players.

An 18-person team will spend three months laying 95 tonnes of poisoned bait to eradicate rodents threatening wildlife at the South Georgia seabird sanctuary, a five-year project to restore the island's unique ecosystem.
The International Criminal Court (ICC) is criticized for its slow and expensive process, with all cases coming from Africa, sparking controversy and questions about its effectiveness.
Finnish electricity company TVO announces that the Olkiluoto 3 nuclear plant, originally due to be completed by 2009, will not meet its latest deadline of 2014 due to ongoing construction delays.

Scottish athlete Jake Butchart broke the 36-year-old Scottish 5,000m record with a time of 13:13.30, securing a second Olympic qualifying standard and easing pressure ahead of the British Championships.
A Scottish dog, Molly, was discovered to be a male pseudohermaphrodite, having both male and female genitalia, and underwent surgery to correct the anatomical issues.
Derbyshire's Godleman scored 105 not out and 108 in his first two innings, helping his team declare on 234-5 against Kent in a rain-affected match.
The University of Reading has officially opened its new campus in Iskandar, Malaysia, a 3,000-student facility featuring an atrium and designed to promote research and economic growth in the region.
Stephen Clarke, 59, appeared in court on a charge of dangerous driving following a fatal motorway incident in 2014 that resulted in the death of Faranza Kousar.
Sina, the parent company of Weibo, reported a net profit of $44.5 million in the fourth quarter, driven by a 163% jump in advertising revenue, despite a decline in user numbers.
Two rookie police officers in Brighton, UK, shared a video and offensive message on social media about the Shoreham Airshow crash that killed 11 people, causing distress to the victims' families.

Daimler is facing a court case for allegedly violating EU regulations by using a non-compliant refrigerant in its Mercedes cars, despite Germany's Federal Motor Transport Authority rejecting its safety concerns.

Venture capitalist Peter Thiel, who funded Hulk Hogan's lawsuit against Gawker, should accept public scrutiny and criticism for using his wealth to silence the media, according to Gawker's Nick Denton.
Prince William and Kate Middleton are taking action against a photographer who was spotted near their 14-month-old son Prince George in a London park, accusing him of stalking and harassment.

Prime Minister David Cameron and former TUC general secretary Brendan Barber warn that a UK exit from the EU would lead to job losses and wage cuts, harming working people and the poorest in the country.
Amateur rocket enthusiasts have gathered in Scotland to celebrate 30 years of International Rocket Week, marking the anniversary of the first Scottish Rocket Weekend in 1986.
A woman in her 30s was sexually assaulted in Langdale Common, Witney, early Saturday morning after being struck in the face and approached from behind by an offender who fled the scene.

Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir's return from exile is celebrated as a victory, with many praising South Africa and the African Union for refusing to arrest him and instead allowing him to return to power.
The PSNI has apologized for retaining body parts and tissue samples from 64 families without informing them, and is now contacting relatives to explain the reasons and offer to return the items.
British swimmer Keri-Anne Payne failed to qualify for the Rio Olympics, finishing 4th in the 10km open water event, but will have another chance to qualify at the Olympic qualification event in June.
A nun who was raped by a repairman at her convent in Chile was pressured to leave the Church and was blamed for the attack, leading her to sue the Archbishopric and her order.

Nigerian striker Asisat Oshoala joins Liverpool Ladies, becoming the first African player in the Women's Super League, after impressing with her performances in the Under-20 World Cup and African Women's Championship.
Devon's rugby team, second in the Premiership, secured a bonus-point win over Sale, but their coach Baxter acknowledges the team needs a break after 30 weekends of consecutive matches without a rest.
A report on HMP Dovegate found the Category B prison has struggled with violence, understaffing, and poor conditions, despite praise for its living conditions and resettlement work.
Hereford United's owner has assured staff and football creditors that payments will be made in full, subject to the club's Conference status, amid concerns over potential expulsion from the league.
Former Wham! star Andrew Ridgeley was injured in a car accident in Hertfordshire, but no further action will be taken due to not wearing a seatbelt.
Security staff at 11 airports in Scotland staged a 48-hour walkout over pay, with the company offering a formal proposal to resolve the dispute and the union welcoming the move.
The UK government has introduced two new stalking offences, carrying maximum sentences of six months and five years, to improve policing and justice for the estimated 120,000 annual victims.

Oscar-winning director Oliver Stone praises Indian cinema's vitality and versatility, stating he would make a movie in India if he found a great story, citing his past experience filming in the country.
Aston Martin reported a £5.9m pre-tax profit for the first quarter, driven by strong sales of its new DB11 model, with revenues more than doubling to £188m.
Russell Westbrook became the second player in NBA history to average a triple-double for an entire season, setting multiple records and winning the NBA Most Valuable Player award.
Patricia Connors, a loving mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, died after being struck by a vehicle on the M4 motorway near Cardiff Gate services in South Wales.
A group of five men in north Wales were accused of operating a predatory paedophile ring in the 1970s and 80s, targeting vulnerable children aged 10-15 and repeatedly abusing them.
England thrashed Scotland 61-0 in a record-breaking Six Nations match, with six tries and 60 points scored, as the Scots suffered a crushing defeat at Twickenham.

Leanne Wood, leader of Plaid Cymru, sharply criticized Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones and the Labour party's handling of the M4 relief road project, accusing them of evasion and lack of engagement.
A new drone prototype, resembling a helicopter, allows a passenger to sit inside and is controlled by a tablet, with a 23-minute flying time and 2-4 hour charging time.

Paul Chichester, head of the London-based NCSC, emphasized the importance of cyber security in Wales, urging businesses and citizens to invest time and energy to protect against constant threats and exploits.
The BBC is reviving its iconic music show, Top of the Pops, with a new series featuring live performances, sketches, and interviews, set to debut in the autumn.
Canadian opera singer Jon Vickers, known for his powerful and distinctive voice, has died at age unknown after a prolonged struggle with Alzheimer's disease.
Adele surprised firemen at a Chelsea fire station with a visit, having a cup of tea and joining a minute's silence with the team, showing her support for those affected by the tower block fire.

Chinese authorities detained at least five women's rights activists, including founders of women's and gay rights groups, ahead of International Women's Day, amid increased security ahead of China's annual parliamentary session.

The British Library's "Magna Carta for the digital age" project allows the public to vote on 500 clauses, with the top 10 revealing a desire for an impartial internet free from government censorship and commercial control.

The Scottish Sentencing Council will research and develop guidelines for sentencing young people, death by driving, environmental and wildlife offences, and sexual crimes to improve public confidence in court decisions.
Dumbarton won 3-1 against Raith Rovers, ending their three-game losing streak and extending Raith's winless run to 12 league and cup matches.
Police are investigating an "unexplained death" after responding to a call at a house in Clermiston, with inquiries ongoing and a report to be sent to the procurator fiscal.
Police seized £1m worth of cannabis plants and arrested six individuals after raiding a former Ministry of Defence bunker in Wiltshire, converted into a large-scale cannabis production facility.

Astronomers have detected a potential "exomoon" orbiting a Jupiter-mass planet, with a size and mass similar to Neptune, using NASA's Kepler Space Telescope and plan to verify the finding with Hubble.

Norwich City thrashed Blackburn Rovers 4-1 in their season opener, with Jacob Murphy scoring a stunning 25-yard goal and Wes Hoolahan, Cameron Jerome, and Steven Naismith adding to the Canaries' tally.

British Prime Minister David Cameron defends Britain's standing in the world, saying it has a proud history, big heart, and greater resilience, after a Russian official reportedly called Britain "no one pays any attention to".
Swansea City manager Francesco Guidolin believes his team's 1-0 win over Chelsea has secured their Premier League safety, with the 40-point mark widely regarded as a guarantee of top-flight survival.
A woman died from severe burns after a kitchen fire in her top-floor flat in a sheltered housing complex in Ardnaclowney House, with three others treated for smoke inhalation.

Here are the highlights:

Daniel Radcliffe gains £20 million fortune on his 18th birthday, but vows to spend wisely.
He plans to buy books, CDs, and DVDs, not flashy cars or party hard.
Radcliffe's earnings from Harry Potter films are held in trust, which he can now access.
He's determined to avoid the "kid star gone wild" stereotype and stay grounded.

Here are the highlights:

Inmates with severe mental illnesses are housed on the "forgotten floor" of Miami's pretrial detention facility.
Many are arrested for avoidable felonies, often due to confrontations with police.
Judge Steven Leifman advocates for justice and mental health treatment for inmates.
A new mental health facility will divert some inmates from the "forgotten floor" to treatment.

Here are the highlights:

The Minneapolis bridge collapsed, sending vehicles into the Mississippi River, with 55 people rescued in under two hours.
Survivors described a chaotic scene, with cars in the water and people injured or trapped.
Gary Babineau, a survivor, helped lift children from a school bus and carried some to safety.
Rescue efforts were hindered by the river's fast current and lack of access to the scene.

Here are the highlights:

President Bush had five small polyps removed from his colon on Saturday.
None of the polyps appeared worrisome, according to White House spokesman Scott Stanzel.
The procedure was routine and Bush is in good humor, resuming activities at Camp David.
Results of the examination are expected in two to three days.

Here are the highlights:

NFL suspends Michael Vick indefinitely without pay due to dogfighting ring involvement.
Vick admits to participating in dogfighting ring, killing dogs that didn't fight well.
NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell calls Vick's actions "cruel and reprehensible".
Vick to appear in court Monday to plead guilty to federal charges.

Here are the highlights:

Youssif, a 5-year-old Iraqi boy, was set on fire and severely burned on January 15.
His parents told CNN they tried to get help in Baghdad, but to no avail.
The Children's Burn Foundation will cover medical costs and provide support for Youssif's recovery.
Youssif and his family will travel to the US for treatment and care.

Here are the highlights:

Iraqi women are turning to prostitution to feed their families, often for as little as $8 a day.
Suha, a 37-year-old mother of three, says she's forced to sell her body to support her children.
Karima, a 35-year-old widow, turned to prostitution after her husband's death, citing desperation and fear.
Women are driven to prostitution by poverty, violence, and lack of government aid in Iraq.

Here are the highlights:

Colombian military killed key rebel commander Tomas Medina Caracas in an air attack on a guerrilla encampment.
Medina Caracas was a fugitive from a US drug trafficking indictment and helped manage FARC's cocaine trafficking network.
He was also indicted in the US for conspiring to kidnap two US oil workers and holding one for ransom.
Fourteen rebels were killed in the attack, including Medina Caracas, along with 14 weapons and communications equipment.

Here are the highlights:

Tony Snow, White House press secretary, will step down on September 14 due to health reasons.
He will be replaced by deputy press secretary Dana Perino.
Snow is undergoing treatment for cancer, which has recurred after initially being in remission.
He plans to continue speaking out on issues and may do some radio and TV work.

Here are the highlights:

A rocket launcher tube was found on a Jersey City, New Jersey, lawn on Friday morning.
The 20-year-old AT4 anti-tank launcher tube was turned over to U.S. Army officials.
The launcher is no longer operable and not considered a hazard to public safety.
Investigation is ongoing to determine its origin and how it ended up on residential property.

President Bush will argue against pulling out of Iraq by invoking Vietnam War lessons.
He'll say withdrawal emboldened terrorists and led to innocent deaths.
Bush will also compare Iraq to Japan and Korea, citing successful transformations.
He'll urge patience and trust in the surge, citing historical precedents.

Here are the highlights:

• June 29, 2007: Police defuse a bomb in Haymarket, London, containing 200 liters of fuel, gas cylinders, and nails.
• July 21, 2005: Four men allegedly attempt to carry out a second wave of attacks on London's transport network.
• July 7, 2005: Four suicide bombers detonate themselves on London's underground trains and a bus, killing 52 people.
• August 2004: Anti-terrorist police disrupt a plot to blow up targets in southeast England using explosives-packed limousines and vehicles.

Carlos Alberto joins Werder Bremen for a club record 7.8 million euros.
He previously played for FC Porto and Corinthians, winning several titles.
Carlos Alberto aims to win titles with Werder Bremen, his new club.
He joins Bundesliga club Werder Bremen on a permanent transfer.

Here are the highlights:

Vice President Dick Cheney to serve as acting president during President Bush's colonoscopy.
Procedure to take about 2 1/2 hours at Camp David, Maryland.
Bush's doctor recommends repeat procedure every 5 years due to previous normal results.
President encourages everyone to get screened for colon cancer starting at age 50.

A magnitude 4.2 earthquake struck the San Francisco area at 4:42 a.m. PT, US Geological Survey reported.
About 2,000 customers lost power, but no injuries or significant damage were reported.
The quake was centered two miles east-northeast of Oakland, at a depth of 3.6 miles.
It lasted about 50 seconds and was considered "light" by the USGS.

Federal official says "no remaining hope" of finding six trapped miners alive in Utah coal mine.
Rescue efforts exhausted after 25 days, with no signs of life or sound from miners.
Microphones pick up no sound, and oxygen levels too low to sustain human life.
Search effort suspended, with families left to mourn the loss of their loved ones.

Here are the highlights:

At least 14 killed, 60 wounded in bomb blast in Batna, Algeria, near President Abdel-Aziz Bouteflika's visit.
Bomb exploded 20 meters from a mosque, 15 minutes before president's expected arrival.
Suspect attempted to breach security cordon, escaped after bomb exploded, officials said.
President Bouteflika visited hospital to see wounded, made no immediate comment on attack.

Here are the highlights:

David Beckham signs five-year contract with Los Angeles Galaxy, leaving Manchester United and England.
Beckham's journey from east London to Hollywood Hills includes playing for Manchester United and England.
He's a fashion icon, celebrity, and multimillion-dollar heartthrob with endorsement deals and a clothing line.
Beckham's family will adapt to life in Los Angeles, a city of glamour and celebrity endorsements.

Here are the highlights:

Honey bees in Australia may be carrying a virus linked to colony collapse disorder in US bees.
Israeli Acute Paralysis Virus (IAPV) was found in 96% of bees from collapsed colonies.
Researchers believe IAPV is not the sole cause, but rather one of several factors.
Australian bees are resistant to IAPV, possibly due to genetic differences or environmental factors.

Savers queue to withdraw cash from Northern Rock bank in London after profit forecast cut.
Customers withdraw £1 billion since woes revealed, sparking global credit crunch concerns.
Bank of England bails out Northern Rock, assuring customers to "use accounts in the usual way".
Shares drop 30% as problems spread to European banking sector, sparking panic.

Here are the highlights:

O.J. Simpson arrested on robbery and assault charges in Las Vegas hotel room.
Simpson accused of directing men to take sports memorabilia, including some not belonging to him.
Police recovered two firearms used in the alleged robbery, but Simpson was not seen with one.
Simpson faces prospect of another prosecution, over a decade after his acquittal for murder.

Nigeria's TV show "Gulder Ultimate Search" suspended after contestant Anthony Ogadje, 25, drowns in preparation.
Ogadje died suddenly while attempting physical challenges at Shere Hills Lake in Plateau State.
The show, sponsored by Heineken, was set to start broadcasting on Thursday.
The winner was to receive 5 million naira in cash and other prizes.

Here are the highlights:

Roy Lynn Oakley, 67, indicted for stealing nuclear energy-related materials from East Tennessee Technology Park.
Oakley allegedly took classified materials in January and attempted to sell them to a French agent.
He faces up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine for each count.
Oakley's lawyer claims he had a low-level security clearance and was just doing his job.

John Terry's fitness uncertain for Chelsea's Champions League match with Valencia due to broken cheekbone.
Terry trained with a face mask on after surgery, but Grant will decide on his availability.
Frank Lampard ruled out of the match due to thigh injury.
Michael Essien expected to play after recovering from leg injury.

Here are the highlights:

Paul Lee got a liver transplant from an executed Chinese prisoner in China.
Karam bought a kidney for his sister in Egypt for $5,300.
Doctors in Pakistan have been arrested for abducting people and stealing their kidneys.
Demand for organs exceeds supply, driving a black market trade.

Lindsay Lohan's legal troubles may affect her ability to secure movie roles, insurance experts say.
Insurance companies may charge higher rates or set strict conditions for covering her films.
Experts say no actor is uninsurable, but some may be too expensive to cover.
Lohan's latest arrest may impact her role in the film "Poor Things", produced by Shirley MacLaine.

Francesco Totti threatens to quit Italian Players Association over starting date of Serie A season.
Totti complains that players are never listened to and wants August 19 start date.
Italian Football League ignored request to start season midway through August.
Serie A is one of the last major European leagues to start next season.

Blackwater denies allegations of illegal arms activities and complicity in unlawful activities.
US government investigating Blackwater employees for illegally purchasing and selling weapons in Iraq.
Company fired two employees after discovering internal theft and invited ATF to investigate.
Blackwater resumed normal operations in Iraq after a brief hiatus following deadly incident.

Here are the highlights:

Youssif, a 5-year-old burned Iraqi boy, meets his favorite superhero Spider-Man at Universal Studios.
Spider-Man gives Youssif a hug and shows him how to shoot a web from his wrist.
The boy and his family enjoy a day of fun at the theme park, forgetting their nightmares.
Youssif's father says this is the happiest day of his life, a welcome respite from war and violence.

Here are the highlights:

Marine Cpl. Trent D. Thomas sentenced to reduction in rank and discharge for Iraqi civilian's death.
Found guilty of kidnapping and conspiracy to commit murder and other offenses.
Thomas will be demoted to entry-level private and receive bad-conduct discharge.
He was among 8 Marines and a Navy medic charged in the 2006 death in Hamdaniya, Iraq.

Here are the highlights:

Prince Harry led tributes to his mother, Diana, Princess of Wales, on her 10th death anniversary.
He described her as "the best mother in the world" and "fun-loving, generous, down-to-earth, entirely genuine".
The Princess's public work included her support for those with Aids and her efforts to overcome a harmful taboo.
Her legacy continues to inspire, and Prince Harry and Prince William still think of her every day.

Here are the highlights:

French Foreign Minister Bernard Kouchner warns France may go to war with Iran over its nuclear program.
Kouchner has a reputation for challenging convention and authority, not afraid to break the law.
He is a humanitarian and patriot with a strong commitment to human rights and international law.
France's new high-profile style under President Nicolas Sarkozy emphasizes a tough stance on Iran's nuclear program.

Here are the highlights:

• "Für Elise" was written by Ludwig van Beethoven, but not for a girl named Elise, as most historians believe.
• "Philadelphia Freedom" was written by Elton John & Bernie Taupin for Billie Jean King, a tennis star.
• "Lola" was written by Ray Davies of The Kinks, but the inspiration remains unclear, with two different stories told.
• "867-5309/Jenny" was written by Jim Keller and Alex Call, but the inspiration and the woman remain unknown.

Here are the highlights:

Historic spending expected in 2008 election cycle, exceeding $3 billion.
Mitt Romney has spent the most on TV ads, $8.6 million so far.
Candidates and interest groups are buying TV time in record numbers.
Television ads could play a crucial role in the 2008 presidential election.

Here are the highlights:

Relatives of 89 plane crash victims arrive in Phuket to identify loved ones' remains.
Most of the 89 killed were foreign nationals, with 36 bodies still unidentified.
US Embassy confirms five Americans were among the dead, with four survivors.
Air traffic controller warned pilots of possible wind shear before the crash.

Michael Moore's new documentary "Sicko" criticizes America's health care system.
Moore and CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta argued over data and facts in the film.
Gupta praised Moore's awareness-raising efforts but criticized the film's solutions.
Moore and Gupta agreed that the US health care system is "broken" and needs fixing.

Here are the highlights:

Democrats waver on House resolution labeling Turkey's treatment of Armenians as genocide.
Turkey threatens to block access to Incirlik Air Base, a key US supply route.
Pentagon prepares alternative routes and supply chains in case of Turkish blockage.
US officials fear Turkish action could complicate Iraq stability and Kurdish rebel attacks.

Here are the highlights:

Twelve-year-old Mohammed Rasoul, injured in a bombing, sits by his cousin's grave in Falluja, Iraq.
He lost his leg and his childhood in the blast, which also killed his 13-year-old cousin.
An American charity, the Global Medical Relief Fund, will send him to the US for treatment.
He will receive a prosthetic leg and undergo further surgery at a Philadelphia hospital.

Here are the highlights:

India elects its first female president, Pratibha Patil, in a vote by parliament and state politicians.
Patil, 72, won about two-thirds of the electoral college votes, despite a scandalous campaign.
Her presidency is seen as a boost for women's rights, with hopes to bring attention to women's issues.
Patil's campaign was marked by controversy, including allegations of financial irregularities and divisive comments.

Here are the highlights:

More than 100 homes in San Diego's La Jolla community evacuated due to 60-yard-wide landslide.
Landslide pulled earth from beneath three-lane road and some multimillion-dollar homes.
Mayor declares state of emergency, seeking aid from California and federal government.
At least 111 homes evacuated, with 75 allowed to return by early Thursday morning.

Here are the highlights:

Most of the 103 children taken by French charity Zoe's Ark are not orphans, but living with their families in Chad.
The charity was accused of kidnapping and concealing the children's identities, and dressing them in bandages and fake IV drips.
The arrested journalists and flight crew said they were unaware of any problems with Zoe's Ark and thought they were on a humanitarian mission.
The International Red Cross, UNHCR, and UNICEF reported that most of the children come from Chadian villages along the Chad-Sudan border.

Explorer Dennis Schmitt discovers an island near Greenland, revealing climate change's impact.
The island was once a peninsula attached to Greenland, but ice melt exposed it.
Many climatologists say arctic ice melt is due to global warming, a trend with severe consequences.
Scientists debate the cause of warming, with some attributing it to natural variability.

Ethiopian soldier's body dragged through Mogadishu streets by angry crowd after gun battles with Islamic insurgents.
19 people killed in clashes, including Ethiopian troops, insurgents, and civilians.
Ethiopian troops arrived in Somalia in December 2006 to back government against Islamic Courts Union.
Fighting drives hundreds more people from their homes, adding to tens of thousands who have fled recently.

Here are the highlights:

Stacy Peterson, 23, missing from suburban Chicago home since October 28, now treated as potential homicide.
Husband, Drew Peterson, 53, a suspect in her disappearance.
Body of Drew Peterson's third wife, Kathleen Savio, to be exhumed for new autopsy.
Authorities suspect foul play in Savio's 2004 death, which was initially ruled an accident.

Here are the highlights:

Julia Vakulenko will face Lindsay Davenport in the Bell Challenge final on Sunday.
Vakulenko won her semifinal match 6-1 4-6 7-5 over Julie Ditty.
Lindsay Davenport seeks her second win in three tournaments since her return from maternity leave.
Davenport defeated Vera Zvonareva 6-2 6-7 (3-7) 6-3 in her semifinal match.

Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf declares state of emergency, suspends constitution, and dismisses top judge.
Troops take over TV station equipment and arrest opposition leader Javed Hashmi and 10 aides.
Musharraf claims actions are necessary to restore order and prevent terrorism.
Supreme Court declares emergency illegal, opposition leaders condemn Musharraf's actions.

Robert A. Singer, 49, arrested and charged with distributing child pornography over the Internet.
Singer, COO of National Children's Museum, allegedly sent images to undercover detective posing as 12-year-old girl and her mother.
Charged with five counts of distributing child pornography in interstate commerce.
Faces up to 140 years in prison if convicted.

Here are the highlights:

Chester Arthur Stiles, 37, appeared in court on charges of raping a 2-year-old girl.
He faces 23 felony counts, including lewdness, sexual assault, and child pornography.
The victim, now 7, was found after a nationwide search and her mother will testify against Stiles.
Stiles' former girlfriends describe him as a violent and controlling individual.

Here are the highlights:

Dale Steyn takes career-best 5-34 as South Africa takes control of first test against New Zealand.
New Zealand bowled out for 118 in reply to South Africa's 226.
Hashim Amla and Jacques Kallis share unbeaten stand of 159 in South Africa's second innings.
South Africa stretches lead to 287, putting pressure on New Zealand.

Here are the highlights:

Laze in a hammock for a relaxing summer evening.
Cut jeans into shorts by folding and ironing the leg, then cutting just under the crease.
Catch fireflies by imitating their blinking pattern with a pen flashlight.
Run on the beach, but beware of soft sand and blisters, and wear shoes for more than a few miles.

Jordan allows all Iraqi children, regardless of refugee status, to enroll in state-funded schools.
145 Iraqi students attend the Shmisani Institute for Girls in Amman, with 40 more on a waiting list.
Jordan expects to accommodate 40,000 to 50,000 Iraqi students this year, double the number two years ago.
The influx puts a strain on schools, with a need for more teachers, resources, and infrastructure.

Here are the highlights:

Michael Mukasey's nomination for attorney general was approved by the Senate with a 53-40 vote.
Mukasey's views on waterboarding threatened to derail his nomination.
He considers waterboarding "repugnant" but cannot categorically say it's torture.
Mukasey's confirmation was assured after key Democrats pledged to support him.

Here are the highlights:

The town of Orme, Tennessee, is experiencing a severe drought, with only 3 hours of water supply per day.
Residents rely on water trucked in from Alabama, with a 1961 fire truck making daily trips to a hydrant.
A pipeline from Bridgeport is nearing completion, funded by a $378,000 federal grant, promising a reliable water supply.
Residents have found creative ways to conserve water, including flushing toilets with condensation water.

Here are the highlights:

China suspends exports of Aqua Dots toys contaminated with "date rape" drug chemical.
Toys cause children to vomit and lose consciousness if ingested.
US recalls 4.2 million toys, while Australian recall affects 1 million.
Children who swallow beads can become comatose, develop respiratory depression, or have seizures.

Tens of thousands of Congolese refugees fled camps in the Democratic Republic of Congo amid rebel attacks.
Refugees were forced to flee due to fighting between government forces and rebels in the area.
The UNHCR reported that some camps were looted, leaving refugees with nothing but what they could carry.
About 28,000 refugees abandoned three camps, while 2,000 left a fourth camp.

Here are the highlights:

Gary Vaynerchuk's online show "Wine Library TV" demystifies wine for a new generation.
He uses unorthodox methods to illustrate wine properties, like licking rocks and eating dirt.
The show has 40,000 daily viewers, mostly 20-somethings, who appreciate his approach.
Wine enthusiasts are increasingly turning to the internet for wine education and community.

Jordanian school accommodates 145 Iraqi students, 20% of its students, due to new government policy.
Iraqi refugees can enroll in state-funded schools without paperwork, regardless of refugee status.
More than 2.2 million Iraqis have fled to Jordan and Syria, with 40,000-50,000 expected to enroll in Jordanian schools.
Iraqi students face challenges, including a four-year educational gap and struggles to integrate into Jordanian society.

Here are the highlights:

Cyclone Sidr kills over 3,100 in Bangladesh, with death toll expected to rise to 5,000 or more.
Thousands are missing, and 280,000 are unable to return to their homes.
The storm destroyed villages and homes, leaving survivors to grieve and bury their loved ones.
International aid organizations promise $25 million in initial aid to help Bangladesh recover.

Italy won 2-1 against Scotland, clinching qualification for Euro 2008.
Luca Toni scored in the 1st and 90th minutes, with Christian Panucci adding the winner.
Scotland's Barry Ferguson equalized in the 65th minute, but Italy held on.
Italy's victory also sealed France's qualification for Euro 2008.

Azerbaijan authorities uncover radical Islamic terror plot against US Embassy in Baku.
Plot targeted US Embassy and Azerbaijani government buildings, officials say.
Suspects arrested in weekend raid, but several remain at large.
US Embassy closes to public, warning Americans to take precautions.

Here are the highlights:

Novak Djokovic crashes out of Paris Masters with a 6-3 6-2 loss to Fabrice Santoro.
Djokovic was struggling due to dental surgery and said he was only 30% of his usual self.
Andy Murray advances to the third round with a 7-6 6-3 win over Jarkko Nieminen.
Rafael Nadal reaches the third round with a 6-3 6-1 victory over Filippo Volandri.

Here are the highlights:

Lipstick is making a comeback, outselling gloss by $76 million last year.
For perfect application, use sheer shades during the day and bold colors at night.
Apply lipstick with a hydrating formula and blot excess oils for a natural look.
Use a gel-based primer and define borders with a pencil for a smooth, long-lasting finish.

Here are the highlights:

Katherine Heigl is the first triple-cover girl for InStyle magazine.
She has a new production company at Fox and is launching a fragrance line.
Heigl is a self-proclaimed beauty enthusiast, loving new products and trends.
She is set to marry musician Josh Kelley in the near future.

Here are the highlights:

• The SPAM Museum in Austin, Minnesota, celebrates 70 years of SPAM with a "wall of SPAM" and a scale model of a SPAM plant.
• The National Museum of Funeral History in Houston features exhibits on embalming, caskets, and fantasy coffins designed by Ghanaian artist Kane Quaye.
• The Hobo Museum in Britt, Iowa, explores the history and culture of tramps with exhibits and a hobo jungle.
• The Mütter Museum in Philadelphia displays unusual medical phenomena, including a world's largest colon and swallowed objects.

Interpol issues global appeal to identify man in digitally reconstructed photos of child sexual abuse.
Man's face was digitally altered, but images can be restored to identify him.
Pictures have been on the internet for years, but his identity and nationality unknown.
Suspect believed to travel to exploit vulnerable children in Vietnam and Cambodia.

Here are the highlights:

Paul Julius Reuter opened an office in London in 1851, transmitting stock market quotes via cable.
Reuters expanded to other European countries, then to the Far East and South America.
The company pioneered radio and teleprinter news transmission, and now has 16,900 staff globally.
Reuters supplies news to 131 countries, with 90% of revenue from financial services.

Here are the highlights:

Six University of South Carolina students killed in a massive house fire in Ocean Isle Beach, North Carolina.
Seven people died, including one believed to be a Clemson University student.
Six survivors, also USC students, were treated and released from the hospital.
The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

Attacks down 75% in northeastern Baghdad, with security "dramatically improving", says US military officer.
Concerned citizens and local leaders helping to improve security in parts of Baghdad.
Iran-backed Shiite militants remain a threat, despite progress against al Qaeda in Iraq.
US troops and Iraqi forces working together to improve security and services.

Here are the highlights:

Authorities search for driver of white truck seen near Santiago fire, now 27,000 acres and still burning.
A $250,000 reward is offered for information leading to the arrest of the person or persons responsible.
Arson charges filed against five people in separate incidents, none linked to major wildfires.
Over 1,600 homes destroyed in past week due to Southern California wildfires.

John Lewis partnership started as a single shop on Oxford Street in London in 1864.
The organization now has bases throughout the UK, employing 67,100 people.
All permanent staff are Partners, owning 26 department stores and 183 supermarkets.
Bonus for 2006 was 18%, equivalent to 9 weeks' pay, for every employee.

Here are the highlights:

Qualcomm was founded in 1985 by seven industry veterans with a focus on CDMA technology.
The company's first product was OmniTRACS, a satellite-based commercial mobile system for transportation.
Qualcomm holds approximately 6,100 US patents and patent applications for CDMA and related technologies.
The company has annual revenue of $7.53 billion and net income of $2.47 billion.

Here are the highlights:

A 7-year-old girl who was sexually assaulted in a videotape has been found safe in Las Vegas.
Chester Arthur Stiles, 37, is a suspect and is being sought by police.
The girl was found with family members after thousands of tips poured in.
Stiles is a distant friend of the girl's family and has a history of carrying a weapon.

Here are the highlights:

Alfred Hitchcock, a cinematic genius, was notoriously hard on actors, calling them "cattle".
Ayn Rand, author of "The Fountainhead" and "Atlas Shrugged", believed in her own philosophy and ranked herself with Aristotle and Thomas Aquinas.
Orson Welles, creator of "Citizen Kane", was convinced of his own importance and had an oversized ego.
Frank Lloyd Wright, a renowned architect, believed he was superior to mere mortals and often acted accordingly.

Kaka named European player of the year, winning France Football's Ballon d'Or award.
Kaka's success comes two years after fellow Brazilian Ronaldinho won the award.
He was a key factor in AC Milan's Champions League campaign and top scorer in the league.
He has now won all major prizes, individually and collectively, at 25 years old.

BUPA is an international health and care company with over 8 million customers.
Founded in 1947 to provide health care choice in the UK's National Health Service era.
BUPA offers health insurance, care homes, and medical services in 8 countries.
Sanitas, BUPA's Spanish business, has 1 million insured customers and 18,000 medical professionals.

Here are the highlights:

Seven college students died in a weekend fire at a North Carolina beach house.
The owner's 18-year-old daughter survived but was hospitalized with smoke inhalation.
Two college campuses, University of South Carolina and Clemson, mourned the loss.
Fire officials do not believe foul play was involved in the fire.

Here are the highlights:

Children as young as 15 are becoming involved in terrorist-related activity in the UK.
At least 2,000 people in Britain pose a threat to national security due to al Qaeda support.
Terrorist plots on British soil are increasingly inspired by al Qaeda cadres in Iraq and East Africa.
Russia continues to devote resources to spying on the UK, diverting attention from counter-terrorism efforts.

Here are the highlights:

Immigration opponents fear changes in local culture, not just practical concerns like border security and social services.
Restrictionists often take the low road, harking back to nativism that greeted earlier waves of immigrants.
Fear of cultural change is driving the debate, not just legal or illegal immigration.
Hispanic immigrants are seen as threatening American identity and culture, sparking nativist rhetoric.

Mauro Camoranesi scores with 13 minutes left to earn Juventus a 1-1 draw with Inter Milan.
Julio Cruz gives Inter the lead in the first half with a goal past Gianluigi Buffon.
Inter retains its unbeaten record this season, two points clear of Fiorentina at the top.
Juventus remains in fourth place after the draw, with Roma a point behind.

Australian soldier, three civilians, and Taliban militants killed in fighting in southern Afghanistan.
Australian commando, 26-year-old Pvt. Luke Worsley, died in close quarter fighting in Uruzgan province.
Taliban insurgents initiated the firefight, killing a significant number of militants or capturing others.
Civilians, two women and a child, died in the crossfire, exact circumstances unknown.

Here are the highlights:

Eight people, including the school's headmistress, were killed in a shooting at Jokela High School in Finland.
The 18-year-old gunman, Pekka Eric Auvinen, died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound.
Auvinen had published a manifesto online demanding war on the "weak-minded masses" and pledging to die for his cause.
He had posted videos on YouTube showing himself firing weapons and had a fascination with killing.

Here are the highlights:

David Trezeguet omitted from France squad for friendlies against Morocco and Ukraine.
Trezeguet has scored 10 goals in 11 Serie A matches for Juventus this season.
Hatem Ben Arfa and Karim Benzema included in the squad, despite injuries.
France need at least a point against Ukraine to qualify for Euro 2008.

Warren Jeffs, polygamist sect leader, attempted to hang himself in jail in January.
He confessed to "immorality" with a "sister" and a daughter over 30 years ago.
Jeffs was convicted of being an accomplice to rape and awaits sentencing.
He faces up to life in prison in November.

Lewis Hamilton spun out of the Chinese Grand Prix, losing his 12-point lead to Fernando Alonso.
Alonso finished second, moving within seven points of Hamilton in the championship.
Kimi Raikkonen won the race, his fifth victory of the season, ahead of Felipe Massa.
Hamilton's mistake leaves the title race wide open heading into the final race in Brazil.

CNN hosts master classes on modern business strategies in Shanghai, New York, and London.
Howard Schultz, Starbucks chairman, will participate in a live discussion and Q&A.
Schultz will share best practices for success in today's business world.
Event airs on November 10 and 11 at various times in Hong Kong.

Here are the highlights:

Sheikh Mohammed bin Isa Al Khalifa is concerned the nuclear dispute with Iran is deterring potential investors in Bahrain.
Bahrain is pushing ahead with economic reforms to reduce dependence on oil and enter the post-oil era.
The country's strengths lie in its human capital and long-standing regulations in financial services.
The Gulf Cooperation Council is speaking with a unified voice to resolve the Iranian nuclear issue.

Here are the highlights:

A powerful bomb ripped off the UN headquarters in Algiers, leveling nearby offices and killing at least 26 people.
Two suspected car bombs struck Algiers within 10 minutes of each other, causing widespread destruction.
The UN reports 45 people killed, while hospital sources say 76 died in the blasts.
Al-Qaeda Islamic Maghreb claimed responsibility for the attacks, citing the need to defend the Islamic nation.

Here are the highlights:

Lionel Messi scored for the sixth game in a row in Barcelona's 3-0 win over Atletico Madrid.
Messi scored twice in four minutes, with Deco and Xavi adding goals later in the match.
Barcelona's victory keeps them in touch with Primera Liga leaders Real Madrid.
Real Madrid won 2-0 against Recreativo Huleva, staying two points ahead of Barcelona.

Here are the highlights:

Formula 1 returns to Fuji Speedway, a circuit that hasn't hosted a race since 1977.
The track features a long main straight and twisty corners, requiring a balance of speed and grip.
Teams use computer simulations to prepare for the new circuit, analyzing every bend and camber.
The goal is to predict lap times and top speed within one percent of actual values.

Celtic fined $50,800 by UEFA for lack of organization and supporter conduct.
Dida, Milan goalkeeper, banned for two matches for breaching UEFA's principles.
Fan who invaded pitch, making minimal contact with Dida, banned for life.
Celtic's fine partially suspended for two years, with half remaining pending.

White House blasts Democrats for not sending veterans' care funding bill to President's desk by Veterans Day.
Democrats attached funding to domestic spending bill, which President threatened to veto.
President wants "clean legislation" to fund veterans, without added spending or taxes.
Congressional leaders blame Republicans for stalling funding, while White House blames Democrats.

Three University of Texas students found alive after day-long search in Airman's Cave in Austin, Texas.
The students, two women and one man, were reported missing early Sunday morning.
They were located about halfway down the 12,000-foot-long cave, which is primarily explored by experienced spelunkers.
Rescuers found the students shortly before 5 p.m. Sunday, about 30 hours after they entered the cave.

Laura Bush urges Myanmar's military junta to step aside and allow democratic transition.
She calls for release of Aung San Suu Kyi and other opposition leaders.
The regime's position grows weaker by the day, Bush warns.
U.S. believes it's time to start preparing for a transition in Myanmar.

President Bush vetoed a $600 billion spending bill, citing wasteful spending and potential tax increases.
The bill would have funded departments of Labor, Education, and Health and Human Services.
Bush accused Democrats of plotting tax increases and urged Congress to cut spending.
He said Congress should send a "responsible measure" for him to sign into law.

Sebastien Chabal cited for dangerous tackle on Simon Shaw in World Cup semifinal.
He faces disciplinary hearing on Monday and may miss third-place match.
France coach Bernard Laporte says defeat was tougher to take than in 2003.
England's Jonny Wilkinson had issues with match balls during the semifinal.

Here are the highlights:

A Colorado man spent $10,000 on security after testifying against his daughter's abusive boyfriend.
He received threats, including a death threat from the boyfriend himself.
The state's witness protection program is under scrutiny, with some calling it a "joke".
The program has a limited budget and provides minimal support to witnesses.

Here are the highlights:

New footage of Princess Diana and Dodi Fayed taken hours before her death has been shown at the inquest.
The footage shows the couple entering an elevator at the Ritz Hotel in Paris.
The inquest is investigating the cause of Diana's death in a car crash on August 31, 1997.
The jury will hear "intimate" details of Diana's personal life, including claims of an engagement ring.

Here are the highlights:

Retired Lt. Gen. Ricardo Sanchez criticizes Iraq war, calling it "a nightmare with no end in sight."
Sanchez blames politicians for dereliction of duty, saying they have cost American lives.
Sen. Lindsey Graham responds, saying Sanchez's own record in Iraq is blemished and he should have spoken out earlier.
Sanchez says politicians prioritize power over lives, while Sen. John McCain says Sanchez should have resigned if he disagreed with the war.

Here are the highlights:

The GOP debate turned heated as candidates attacked each other on issues like immigration and the Iraq war.
Rudy Giuliani and Mitt Romney clashed over immigration, with Giuliani accusing Romney of having a "sanctuary mansion".
John McCain and Ron Paul disagreed on the Iraq war, with McCain calling Paul's views "isolationist".
The candidates also discussed gun control, abortion, and the Bible, with some expressing differing views.

Here are the highlights:

Iraqi detainees freed in recent weeks have not broken their pledge not to return to the insurgency.
Detainees receive free medical care, food, education, and job skills in U.S. detention centers.
1,000-plus detainees have been released, with none returning to threaten Iraqi or coalition forces.
Detainees have a chance to take classes up to a sixth-grade level, with 8,000 in school.

Here are the highlights:

Tennessee Supreme Court refuses to modify or overturn visitation rights for Mary Winkler with her three daughters.
Winkler was convicted of killing her husband, a minister, and has not seen her children in 15 months.
The children have been living with their grandparents since Winkler's arrest.
Winkler's attorney says she is "absolutely elated" and hopes to see her children before Christmas.

Here are the highlights:

Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf orders two TV networks off the air at request.
GEO-TV and ARY Digital were banned from Pakistan's cable TV system since November 3.
Networks offered news, entertainment, sports, and music programming worldwide via satellite.
Government demands included "dulling down" content and removing certain anchors and hosts.

Four people killed, several injured in explosion at chemical plant in Jacksonville, Florida.
Thick plume of smoke rises from plant, causing evacuation and air quality concerns.
Fourteen people hospitalized, six transported to Shands Hospital with injuries.
Firefighters battling hot spots, effort expected to continue for "quite some time".

Here are the highlights:

Nasser al Ansari is the CEO of Qatari Diar, a state-owned real estate investment company.
Qatari Diar was established in 2004 to support Qatar's growing economy and real estate development.
The company has 18 projects underway and is valued at $1 billion.
Qatari Diar invests in real estate worldwide, including Morocco, Sudan, Syria, Egypt, and Europe.

Here are the highlights:

New Jersey banned executions, becoming the first state to do so in 42 years.
Capital punishment dropped to a 13-year low, with 42 executions this year.
The Supreme Court will hold oral arguments on lethal injection protocols in January.
Forty-two people were put to death this year, a 57% drop from 1999.

Zenit Saint Petersburg win their first Russian title since 1984 with a 1-0 victory over Ramenskoye.
Captain Anatoly Timoshuk kisses the Russian Premier League trophy after the win.
Zenit finishes top of the table with 61 points, two points ahead of Spartak Moscow.
Radek Sirl scores the winning goal in the 15th minute with a deflected shot.

Celtic held to 1-1 draw by managerless Hibernian, dropping points in title bid.
David Murphy scored for Hibernian, his second goal against Celtic this season.
Celtic's Gordon Strachan criticizes team's mistakes, saying they need to cut them out.
Celtic's title lead is now just three points from Rangers, who have three games in hand.

Here are the highlights:

Christians in six states prayed along Interstate 35, believing it's the "Highway of Holiness" mentioned in Isaiah 35.
Churchgoers in Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas, Missouri, Iowa, and Minnesota participated in the 35-day prayer campaign.
They prayed for safety, freedom from crime, and for people to accept Jesus into their lives.
Some believe intense prayer is needed to fulfill the prophecy of I-35 being a holy highway.

Venezuela raises taxes on alcohol and cigarettes to cut consumption and reduce social, economic, and moral consequences.
Alcohol prices increased by 10%, cigarettes by 20%, with taxes on whiskey and other drinks rising $1.79 per liter.
Stores near schools, churches, and cultural centers will no longer be allowed to sell alcohol.
Taxes on cigarette imports also increased from 50% to 70% of the total price.

Here are the highlights:

Former President Clinton calls obesity the No. 1 health crisis in the US, requiring immediate action.
Two-thirds of adult Americans are overweight or obese, and one-third of US children are the same.
Experts propose solutions like healthy school lunches, trans fat elimination, and community-based efforts.
Clinton emphasizes education and motivation, saying "there's no shame, there's no embarrassment" in a healthy lifestyle.

Yuvraj Singh smashes six sixes in one over, helping India beat England in the World Twenty20 tournament.
England crashes out of the tournament, eliminated at the Super Eights stage.
South Africa beats New Zealand by six wickets, keeping their semifinal hopes alive.
India's Yuvraj Singh reaches the fastest 50 in Twenty20 history, needing just 12 deliveries.

Here are the highlights:

Chester Arthur Stiles, 37, arrested for videotaped rape of toddler in Las Vegas, to appear in court Friday.
Stiles was taken into custody Monday night after a traffic stop in Henderson, Nevada.
Former girlfriend Elaine Thomas identified Stiles as the suspect after seeing enhanced photos on TV.
Stiles faces 20 counts related to the videotaped rape, including sexual assault and attempted sexual assault.

Here are the highlights:

Eduardo Gonzalez, a US Navy petty officer, faces deployment while his wife may be deported to Guatemala.
He worries about his young son's future if she is deported.
The US military has no policy for dealing with cases like his.
Gonzalez urges officials to consider a policy to keep families together.

Heavy rains and flooding force hundreds of thousands to flee their homes in Mexico's Tabasco state.
About 300,000 people are still trapped by the flooding, which is the worst in 50 years.
The Grijalva River has risen 6.5 feet above its critical level, flooding up to 80% of Villahermosa.
President Felipe Calderon promises federal support, while NGOs urge donations of non-perishable goods and cash.

Here are the highlights:

The UN is calling on NATO to do more to stop the Afghan opium trade, valued at $4 billion in 2007.
Opium accounts for over half of Afghanistan's GDP, with farmers earning a quarter of the earnings.
NATO is concerned about the drug trade's funding of the Taliban insurgency.
NATO is providing assistance to Afghan police, but no plans to deploy troops to intervene directly.

David Nalbandian stunned world No. 1 Roger Federer with a 1-6 6-3 6-3 victory in Madrid.
Nalbandian, ranked 25th, repeated his 2005 upset win over Federer in the season-ending Masters Cup.
He became only the third player to beat the world's top-three players en route to a title.
Nalbandian served well and played strongly to claim his first ATP Tour win since May 2006.

Here are the highlights:

Argentina beat Bolivia 3-0 in World Cup qualifiers, thanks to Juan Roman Riquelme's two goals.
Riquelme scored a spectacular free-kick and a cool sidefoot finish to cap off the match.
Argentina is now five points clear of second-placed Brazil, who play Peru on Sunday.
Argentina's win was marked by a record-breaking appearance by captain Javier Zanetti.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Hillary Clinton criticizes President Bush's plan to withdraw 30,000 troops from Iraq by next summer.
She calls it "too little, too late" and urges Bush to accelerate troop redeployment.
Sen. Barack Obama proposes withdrawing one or two combat brigades per month, completing by end of 2008.
Sen. John Edwards calls for immediate withdrawal of 40,000 to 50,000 troops.

Here are the highlights:

The High Museum of Art in Atlanta hosts "Inspiring Impressionism" exhibition, organized by the Denver Art Museum.
The show explores the influences on Impressionist artists, including Claude Monet, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, and Paul Cézanne.
The exhibition runs through January 2008 and will then travel to Denver and Seattle.
It features works from the Louvre's collection, including pieces by Titian, Velasquez, and Fragonard.

Nemanja Vidic returns from concussion to play for Manchester United against Dynamo Kiev.
Vidic will partner Rio Ferdinand in defense, replacing injured Louis Saha.
Wayne Rooney and Carlos Tevez will partner in attack, looking for a third straight win.
United flew to Kiev a day early to prepare for the Champions League match.

Here are the highlights:

Turkey's treatment of Armenians in World War I sparks controversy in US House.
Resolution labeling killings as genocide passes House committee vote, faces full House vote.
US may set up new supply routes if Turkey blocks access to Incirlik Air Base.
Pentagon prepares for alternative routes, citing 70% of air cargo and 95% of fuel coming from Turkey.

Milan goalkeeper Dida cleared to play in Champions League match at Shakhtar Donetsk.
Dida had one game of two-match ban suspended for a year after appealing to UEFA.
Fined 60,000 Swiss francs for theatrics following Celtic fan's encroachment.
Second match of ban will be served only if Dida commits similar offense within a year.

Reggae legend Lucky Dube killed in attempted car-jacking in Johannesburg, South Africa.
Dube, 43, was shot and died almost instantly while dropping off his children.
He was much loved by fellow South Africans and a respected musician globally.
Dube leaves behind a 25-year music career and a family of eight.

Here are the highlights:

An engine fell from a Boeing 737 during takeoff from Cape Town, South Africa, causing panic among passengers.
The pilot flew the plane to a safe emergency landing, with no injuries reported.
The engine had been in service for only 3,806 hours after a major overhaul in 2005.
An object had been sucked into the engine as it lifted off the ground.

FEMA officials promise a different response to California wildfires compared to Hurricane Katrina.
FEMA Director David Paulison vows to coordinate efforts and respond to needs of affected families.
President Bush signs federal disaster declaration, freeing up funds for wildfire relief in seven counties.
FEMA and relief agencies face different challenges in California wildfires compared to Hurricane Katrina.

Here are the highlights:

Chris Benoit idolized the Dynamite Kid, a professional wrestler known for high-flying moves.
Benoit strangled his wife and son before hanging himself in June.
The Dynamite Kid, Tom Billington, blames wrestling and steroids for his own health issues.
WWE Chairman Vince McMahon denies any responsibility for Benoit's actions, citing a wellness policy.

Here are the highlights:

Roman Princess Justa Grata Honoria's wild ways and ambition led to the fall of the Western Roman Empire.
She plotted with her brother's chamberlain to murder her brother and seize power.
Honoria proposed to Attila the Hun, king of the Huns, to escape her convent life and gain power.
Attila's invasion of Rome in 451 C.E. destroyed the Western Empire, ending its reign.

Sheffield FC celebrates 150th birthday with FIFA chief Blatter and other football dignitaries in attendance.
Sheffield FC is the oldest football club, founded in 1857 by two cricket fans.
The club developed set rules for the game and introduced innovations like heading and floodlights.
Sheffield FC has never played at a professional level, competing in the Unibond League's First Division South.

Here are the highlights:

Pointed shoes were favored by Polish nobles in the 1300s, dubbed "crackowes" or "poulaines".
The sports bra was invented by University of Vermont student Lisa Lindahl in 1977.
Mary Jane shoes were named after a character in the 1900s children's comic strip "Buster Brown".
The term "pump" originated in 1550 England, describing the noise male servants made while wearing the shoes.

Ronaldinho recalled to Barcelona squad for Champions League match against Rangers.
Dropped from previous match for returning late from international duty.
Barcelona will be without Deco due to thigh injury for around five weeks.
Squad includes Messi, Xavi, and Henry, with 100% record in Group E.

Here are the highlights:

Jared Hutchins, a 16-year-old, says the Beatles' music had a negative effect on him.
He attends Christian rallies, like Acquire the Fire and BattleCry, to resist secular culture.
The rallies draw thousands of teenagers and young adults, with a focus on Christianity.
Teen Mania's Ron Luce calls popular culture "the enemy" and "terrorists" harming kids.

Here are the highlights:

Lebanon's civil war erupted when shells rained down on the author's neighborhood in Beirut at age 14.
The author fled to a shelter, recalling the terror and fear of the war.
After a decade of relative peace, bombings and assassinations have returned to Beirut.
The author fears Lebanon's divisions will resurface, threatening the country's fragile peace.

Here are the highlights:

Firefighters battle 15 wildfires in Southern California, forcing hundreds of thousands to flee their homes.
Wildfires have scorched over 400,000 acres, killed one person, and injured at least 70 others.
Santa Ana winds have fueled the fires, making it difficult for air assets to fight the blazes.
Firefighters are aided by resources from Mexico, state and federal governments, and California's prisons.

Here are the highlights:

Sallie Krawcheck, CEO of Citi Global Wealth Management, manages $1.8 trillion in client assets.
She's dubbed the "Mrs. Clean" of Wall Street for her honesty and integrity.
Krawcheck predicts a shift in economic activity from developed to emerging markets.
She believes the US is ready for a woman to run a major money center bank.

Here are the highlights:

One of Southern California's largest fires was deliberately started by someone with arson knowledge.
The Santiago Fire in Orange County burned over 25,000 acres, destroying at least 22 structures.
