Matos was disqualified for taking too much injury time, sparking an angry reaction.
He pushed a judge, kicked the referee, and spat on the floor before being escorted out.
The World Taekwondo Federation is considering a life ban for Matos and his coach.

Here are the highlights:

Marine husband charged with murder of Fort Bragg soldier, 2nd Lt. Holley Wimunc, 24.
Another Marine charged with aiding the crime, authorities say.
Wimunc's body found in woods, but identification pending, police confirm.
Husband and fellow Marine held without bond, awaiting trial.

Esmin Green died on hospital floor after being neglected and ignored by staff.
Family plans to file $25 million lawsuit against city and hospital.
Seven employees fired or suspended, but family wants criminal charges.
Autopsy results not released, but family wants justice and compensation.

Here are the highlights:

Lovemore Moyo becomes Zimbabwe's first opposition speaker of parliament, winning 110 votes.
Moyo, MDC national chairman, vows to ensure passage of progressive laws.
Two MDC members arrested, released, amid allegations of sinister government agenda.
MDC's Morgan Tsvangirai attends swearing-in ceremony, despite objections to parliament's convening.

Violent protests in Kashmir continue, with 20 deaths reported over two days.
Three people who were critically injured in protests die, adding to tensions.
Protests began over land transfer to Hindu shrine, with 200 people injured.
Curfew lifted in Srinagar for several hours, but mob attacks policeman.

Here are the highlights:

Spc. Shaun Gopaul's best friend, Sgt. Alex Jimenez, was ambushed and captured in Iraq's Triangle of Death.
Jimenez, a larger-than-life figure, learned Arabic to talk with Iraqis and cared about his fellow soldiers.
Gopaul tried to keep upbeat while waiting for Jimenez's return, but the military later confirmed his death.
Jimenez's body was returned to the US, along with those of two other soldiers, Pfc. Joseph J. Anzack Jr. and Pvt. Byron W. Fouty.

Here are the highlights:

A roadside bombing in Somalia's capital killed 21 women cleaning a street on Sunday morning.
The bombing also wounded 46 people, most of them Somali women.
The victims were participating in a UN program to work as street cleaners in exchange for food.
The cause of the bombing is unclear, with both government and Islamist groups denying involvement.

Here are the highlights:

Tropical Storm Fay brought high winds and heavy rain to eastern Florida, with 7 possible tornadoes reported.
Fay could strengthen into a hurricane when it swings over Florida again Thursday, according to the National Hurricane Center.
A hurricane watch has been issued for Florida's east coast, from north of Flagler Beach to Altamaha Sound.
Fay's maximum sustained winds remained near 65 mph, with higher gusts, forecasters said.

Here are the highlights:

• US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi reverses opposition to offshore drilling vote, pending a larger energy package.
• Pelosi urges releasing oil from strategic reserves to lower gas prices and invests in renewable energy resources.
• She suggests a vote on offshore drilling as part of a package with renewable energy investments and oil reserve releases.
• Pelosi says she would not vote on a package that only includes offshore drilling without renewable energy investments.

Iran to execute 30 people convicted of drug and criminal charges on Sunday.
Convictions include murder, drug dealing, armed robbery, and smuggling arms.
20 of the condemned were convicted of drug and alcohol-related crimes.
Hangings aim to serve as a warning to those contemplating similar crimes.

Here are the highlights:

Barbara Hillary, 75, became the first African American woman to reach the North Pole.
Maurice Ashley is the first and only African American International Grand Master of Chess.
Bliss Broyard's father was black, a secret revealed just before his death.
Marvin Perkins is a black Mormon elder, a "world's best kept secret".

Here are the highlights:

Senators Barack Obama and John McCain will appear together at a leadership forum in California in August.
The Rev. Rick Warren, author of "The Purpose Driven Life", will moderate the event.
Warren has invited both candidates to speak separately, without a debate format.
Warren, a pastor, does not endorse candidates, but wants to show the "real person" behind each candidate.

Sen. Charles Schumer criticizes OTS for blaming him for IndyMac's failure.
OTS accused Schumer of sparking a bank run with a letter expressing concerns.
Schumer says OTS was "asleep at the switch" and allowed IndyMac's reckless behavior.
IndyMac, with $32 billion in assets, is the fifth bank to fail this year.

Three Americans rescued after 5 years in Colombian captivity, expressing "overwhelmed with emotion" at being back home.
They were among 15 hostages freed in a Colombian military operation, including French-Colombian politician Ingrid Betancourt.
The Americans, Marc Gonsalves, Thomas Howes, and Keith Stansell, are being treated at a Texas hospital.
They thanked Colombian authorities for the "operation that will never be forgotten" and expressed gratitude for their families' support.

Here are the highlights:

Cuba is a place close to my heart, where my family history began.
Over 15,000 Jews lived in Cuba in the 1940s and '50s, now only 1,500 remain.
I visited the Adath Israel synagogue in Havana, where my grandparents were married.
The oldest Jew in Cuba, Salomon Leyderman, recognized my family photos and shared stories.

New Zealand thrashes Samoa 101-14 in one-off rugby union Test, scoring 15 tries.
Mils Muliaina scores three tries in the first half, Conrad Smith and Richard Kahui each score twice.
New Zealand's 100 points is a record score against Samoa, surpassing 71-13 in 1999.
Daniel Carter converts six tries, surpassing 2,000 points in first-class rugby.

Federal investigators will declare the 2001 anthrax case solved, blaming government researcher Bruce Ivins for the attacks.
Ivins, an ex-Army scientist, died from an apparent suicide last week.
The case will not be closed due to administrative details remaining incomplete.
FBI to share evidence with survivors and relatives of victims before making the announcement public.

Here are the highlights:

Oklahoma health officials search for source of rare E. coli strain that killed one person and sickened 116.
Over 50 hospitalized, nine on dialysis, with most cases linked to Country Cottage Restaurant in Locust Grove.
Tests show bacteria present in restaurant's well water, but type not confirmed.
Symptoms include severe diarrhea, bloody diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal cramping.

Here are the highlights:

Hurricane Gustav nears Louisiana's coast, forecasters warn of heavy rains and inland flooding.
Storm could stall over Louisiana and northeast Texas for several days, exacerbating flooding.
Gustav makes landfall in Louisiana, bringing hurricane-force winds and heavy rains to southern coast.
Top winds weakened to 110 mph, downgrading it to a Category 2 storm.

Here are the highlights:

Prachanda, leader of Nepal's former communist rebels, named new prime minister.
Received 464 votes in 601-member constituent assembly, a simple majority.
Will lead coalition government, with talks ongoing on ministerial portfolios.
Prachanda remains supreme commander of Maoist People's Liberation Army.

Here are the highlights:

Hurricane Gustav churned into the Gulf of Mexico as a Category 4 storm, threatening the US Gulf Coast.
Gustav's winds reached 135 mph, with the potential to strengthen further in warmer waters.
A hurricane watch was issued for the northern Gulf Coast, including New Orleans and Lake Pontchartrain.
Thousands of Cubans evacuated to higher ground as Gustav made landfall in western Cuba.

EPA advised employees not to answer questions from journalists, GAO, or inspector general, citing efficiency.
EPA's Office of Inspector General did not approve the language of the warning.
EPA press director says the memo was about efficiency, not secrecy, and is consistent with existing policies.
Sen. Barbara Boxer calls the move "a secretive, dangerous ally of polluters."

Here are the highlights:

Paul Begala says Sarah Palin is unqualified to be president.
McCain chose Palin over more qualified candidates like Tom Ridge and Mitt Romney.
Palin's lack of experience raises questions about McCain's judgment and health.
McCain's age and health become central issues in the campaign.

Here are the highlights:

Transform carryout into crowd-pleasing cuisine with mini pizzas, bruschetta, and more.
Start with large cheese pizza, garlic bread, or chicken stir-fry to create bite-sized snacks.
Add toppings like olives, mushrooms, and goat cheese for a delicious twist.
Heat and serve for a stress-free party spread.

Here are the highlights:

Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie's newborn twins' pictures published for first time.
Magazine bidding war topped $14 million, with Hello! and People magazines sharing costs.
Photos show twins Knox Leon and Vivienne Marcheline, and the rest of the Jolie-Pitt family.
All proceeds go to the Jolie-Pitt Foundation, which supports children in Iraq.

Here are the highlights:

President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner calls for decriminalizing personal drug use and targeting traffickers and dealers.
She believes those with addiction should not be condemned, but rather receive help and treatment.
Argentina's government aims to pass decriminalization legislation by the end of the year.
Decriminalization has been adopted in some European and Latin American countries with positive results.

Here are the highlights:

Siblings Irene Famulak and Wssewolod Galezkij reunited after 66 years apart, separated by Nazis in 1942.
Famulak, 83, was taken to a German labor camp, while Galezkij, 73, was sent to a camp in Ukraine.
They were finally reunited at an airport in Donetsk, Ukraine, with the help of the American Red Cross.
The siblings shared a tearful and joyful reunion, cherishing their long-awaited moment together.

Here are the highlights:

Celebrity gossip columnist Cindy Adams attended the Republican National Convention in St. Paul, Minnesota.
She found the convention less exciting than the Democratic National Convention in Denver, Colorado.
Adams is supporting John McCain's election and wants him to have an equal shot as Barack Obama did.
She is unsure about Sarah Palin, McCain's running mate, and thinks it will take six months to learn about her.

Twenty-nine people convicted of various crimes, including murder and drug dealing, were hanged in Iran.
Convicts were found guilty by the highest judicial authorities and their sentences were carried out on Sunday.
The hangings were intended to serve as a warning to those contemplating similar crimes.
Iran executed 317 people last year, second only to China.

Pakistan's ruling coalition announces plan to impeach President Pervez Musharraf.
Musharraf took power in a 1999 military coup and has been criticized for authoritarian rule.
Lawmakers will demand a vote of confidence before pursuing impeachment proceedings.
Musharraf may still have the power to dissolve parliament and dismiss the prime minister.

Here are the highlights:

Pilot of Barack Obama's plane told air traffic controllers of an emergency during unscheduled landing in St. Louis.
Plane made an unscheduled landing on July 7 due to a control problem with the pitch of the aircraft.
Pilot regained control as the plane descended into St. Louis, and fire trucks met the aircraft on landing.
Obama joked about the incident, saying it was the first time he'd had to make an unscheduled landing.

Here are the highlights:

A helicopter crashed into an oil drilling platform off the coast of Dubai, killing all 7 people on board.
The victims included an American, a Briton, and nationals from India, Pakistan, the Philippines, and Venezuela.
The Bell 212 helicopter crashed on the deck, broke up, and fell into the sea.
A fire broke out on the oil rig, but was quickly contained.

Air traffic delays cleared up Tuesday evening after computer problems at FAA facility.
Flights at Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport were delayed Tuesday afternoon.
Delays began to clear by 5 p.m. ET, with minimal delays remaining by 6 p.m.
Most major airports were reporting flights departing on time or with less than 15-minute delays.

New Zealand police investigate "serious allegation" against four England rugby players at Auckland hotel.
Incident allegedly occurred in private hotel room after England's defeat to All Blacks.
Police investigating, but no formal complaint has been made, and players receive support.
England Rugby Union cooperating with authorities, no further comment available.

Here are the highlights:

About 50 students broke into a Dutch consulate in Indonesia to protest an anti-Islamic film.
The 15-minute film "Fitna" features disturbing images and verses from the Quran to paint Islam as a threat.
Dutch Prime Minister Jan Beter Balkenende worried the film could provoke a violent backlash.
The film has sparked protests in Indonesia and other Muslim-majority countries.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Joe Biden's campaign stop in Missouri sparks debate over stem cell research and special needs children.
Biden says Republicans should support stem cell research, citing his own experience with a child with a developmental disability.
McCain-Palin campaign rebukes Biden, calling his comments a "new low" and a "desperate" political move.
Biden's comments come as Palin's support for special needs children is scrutinized, particularly her stance on stem cell research.

Here are the highlights:

Hurricane Dolly made landfall on South Padre Island, Texas, as a Category 2 hurricane.
The storm brought strong winds and heavy rain, causing damage and flooding to buildings.
At least one person was injured, and over 13,000 customers were without power.
The storm is expected to bring persistent rainfall, causing flooding upstream in the Rio Grande.

Warren Jeffs, polygamist sect leader, released from Las Vegas hospital after being hospitalized for unknown reasons.
He was taken to the hospital from an Arizona jail due to his weakened state.
Jeffs' condition was not believed to be life-threatening, according to authorities.
He is the leader of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

Here are the highlights:

Detroit Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick resigns amid sex and perjury scandal.
He pleads guilty to charges, will serve four months in jail and five years probation.
Kilpatrick admits lying under oath, obstructing justice, and assaulting a police officer.
He will be replaced by City Council President Ken Cockrel Jr. on September 18.

Here are the highlights:

Seattle is ranked as the best city for healthy living, with abundant fresh local foods and walker-friendly streets.
Portland, Oregon, comes in second, with endless outdoor activities, cutting-edge restaurants, and a vibrant environmental consciousness.
Washington, D.C., ranks third, with farm-fresh dining, diverse cultures, and ample opportunities for exploration on foot.
Minneapolis, Minnesota, is fourth, with lush parks and shimmering lakes providing a natural backdrop to a rich cultural landscape.

I-Report initiative launched on CNN.com in 2006 to involve citizens in newsgathering.
Mark Lacroix sent photos of Minneapolis bridge collapse from his apartment window.
I-Reporters submitted over 450 photos and videos within 24 hours of the collapse.
Citizens have been submitting content during major breaking news events since 2006.

Cindy McCain praises husband John McCain as "someone of unusual strength and character".
She introduces Rwandan genocide survivor Ernestine to illustrate the importance of forgiveness.
Cindy McCain recommends John McCain as the next US President, citing his leadership and character.
She ends her speech to the Republican National Convention with applause.

Here are the highlights:

Hurricane Ike grew from Category 1 to Category 4 in 6 hours, with 135-mph sustained winds.
Ike is forecast to regain Category 4 status by Monday, but no land areas affected yet.
Tropical Storm Hanna drenches the Bahamas and Haiti, with 61 deaths reported in Haiti.
Hanna expected to return to hurricane strength by Friday, with landfall predicted in the US southeast.

Here are the highlights:

A secret US military program has contributed to the drop in violence in Iraq, according to a new book by Bob Woodward.
The program is a top-secret operation to locate and kill leaders of al Qaeda in Iraq and other insurgents.
It is similar to the Manhattan Project, which developed the atomic bomb during World War II.
The program has been highly effective, cutting violence in half in a matter of months.

Here are the highlights:

Pete Wentz performed at a Rock the Vote concert at the Democratic National Convention.
He's excited to see young fans energized about the election, even if they can't vote yet.
Illinois is pulling for Obama, thanks to his Chicago roots and hometown support.
Wentz likely votes similarly to his wife Ashlee Simpson, but won't reveal her choice.

Here are the highlights:

Journalist Bob Woodward reveals secret US program to assassinate terrorists in Iraq.
US subcontracted assassination program against al Qaeda in early 2006, reducing violence.
Surge of US troops and neighborhood stations also contributed to decline in violence.
Segregation of Baghdad into enclaves and paying off Sunni insurgents helped bring down violence.

Here are the highlights:

Ross Lovegrove is a renowned industrial designer known for his organic minimalism and "fat-free" design.
He draws inspiration from nature and combines it with cutting-edge technology and manufacturing techniques.
Lovegrove's designs have been exhibited internationally and are held in permanent collections worldwide.
He's working on innovative projects like the "Car on a Stick," an electric bubble car with a streetlight feature.

Randy Pausch, professor and "last lecture" author, dies at 47 of pancreatic cancer.
Pausch's lecture, "Really Achieving Your Childhood Dreams," went viral with over 3.2 million views.
He emphasized joy, persistence, and having fun in his lecture and life.
Pausch was a computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon University.

Here are the highlights:

Hadrian inherited an overstretched Roman Empire in 117AD and pulled troops out of Mesopotamia.
The British Museum's "Hadrian: Empire and Conflict" exhibition opens on July 24.
The exhibition features 180 objects from 11 countries, including a recently unearthed massive bust of Hadrian.
The exhibit explores Hadrian's reign, including his military decisions and personal life.

FBI's most wanted terrorist Fazul Abdullah Mohammed escapes raid in Kenya, evading capture for the third time.
Kenyan police received local intelligence tips, finding two passports linked to Mohammed at the raid location.
A $5 million reward is offered for information leading to his apprehension or conviction.
Mohammed is a senior al Qaeda operative in East Africa, suspected of multiple attacks and bombings.

Here are the highlights:

Two UAE companies, Dana Gas and Crescent Petroleum, invest in Kurdistan's autonomous region.
Kurdistan Gas City project to generate 200,000 jobs, with $3 billion initial investment.
City will feature industrial, residential, and commercial buildings, with $40 billion in foreign investment.
Project to start on September 21, promoting private sector investment in gas-related industries.

British media reacts to a private Abu Dhabi group's planned takeover of Manchester City football club.
Gulf interests in English football are not new, with Emirates, Etihad, and Saudi Telecom already involved.
Sheikha Hanadi al Thani, a Qatari businesswoman, discusses the real estate bubble in Qatar.
Al Waab City, her property development, is set to open in 2010.

Here are the highlights:

The US, EU, and international security organizations call for an end to fighting between Georgia and separatists.
Russia's Prime Minister Vladimir Putin says a real war is going on in South Ossetia.
The US supports Georgia's territorial integrity and urges an immediate ceasefire.
NATO and EU urge all parties to de-escalate tensions and avoid conflict.

The movie "Get Smart" features spy gadgets that are now real, such as a two-way tooth radio and a digital "spy fly".
The film exaggerates existing devices, making them more advanced and comical.
The movie's gadgets are inspired by the original TV series and real-life technology.
Spy gadgets have been a staple in movies, starting with James Bond in 1962.

Here are the highlights:

MENA countries investing heavily in education to combat rising unemployment.
Over 40 prestigious Western universities set up alliances and campuses in the Middle East.
Pnina Rosenblum, founder of Pnina Rosenblum Ltd, shares her story of success from poverty to millionaire.
Rosenblum's cosmetics company generates $8 million a year.

Here are the highlights:

Canada sends warship HMCS Ville de Quebec to Somalia to escort UN aid ships from pirate attacks.
The ship will travel at speeds over 27 knots and is armed with torpedoes and surface-to-air missiles.
The mission aims to ensure safe delivery of food aid to over 2 million people in need.
Canada's move comes after pirate attacks on unescorted ships have increased in the region.

Here are the highlights:

A British soldier's family was forced to leave their home after a camel spider killed their pet dog.
The spider hitched a ride back with the soldier from Afghanistan, where it is common.
The camel spider's bite is not deadly to humans but can kill small animals.
The family is refusing to return home until the spider is caught.

Taliban fighters pose in French uniforms in magazine photo spread, sparking anger and controversy.
Photos show fighters wearing French gear, claiming responsibility for killing 10 French soldiers.
French Defense Minister accuses magazine of promoting Taliban, calling it "despicable".
Paris Match editor defends publication, citing importance of the story and "legitimate" reporting.

Here are the highlights:

Bill Gates no longer world's richest man, replaced by Warren Buffett with an estimated $62 billion fortune.
Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal Alsaud, a Saudi investor, is the Middle East's richest man with $21 billion.
Kuwaiti construction heir Nasser Al-Kharafi has an inherited fortune of $14 billion and ranks 46th.
Naguib Sawiris, a telecoms billionaire, ranks 60th with a net worth of $12.7 billion.

Here are the highlights:

Monsoon flooding in Nepal leaves 50,000 people homeless and kills at least 74 in northern India.
Nepalese army rescues stranded residents using helicopters in southeastern Nepal.
Heavy flooding destroys mud huts and kills at least 74 in Uttar Pradesh, India.
Over 40,000 people displaced, with many living in government-run relief camps.

Here are the highlights:

Mohammed Alshaya's retail empire owns top brands like Topshop and NEXT in the Middle East.
He sees a new mindset in the Gulf, driven by strong leadership and a new generation of entrepreneurs.
Alshaya's annual growth is 25-30% in some cases, with plans to expand into Eastern Europe and Russia.
He prioritizes preserving culture and creating jobs, with a focus on family businesses in the Gulf.

Here are the highlights:

Start the day with yum cha in China Town, then shop at Queen Victoria Building and David Jones.
Walk to Paddington and Woollahra for charming architecture and coffee.
Enjoy lunch at Icebergs restaurant with a view of Bondi Beach, then walk the coastal path.
End the day with sunset drinks at the Opera Bar and dinner at Billy Kwong's or Tetsuya's.

Here are the highlights:

A Justice Department program favored conservative candidates over liberal ones, an investigation found.
Esther Slater McDonald, a political appointee, made disparaging comments about liberal applicants.
The report is the first official investigation into politicization of the Justice Department under Bush.
The hiring process was changed in 2007 to insulate decisions from political considerations.

Here are the highlights:

Hanna weakened from hurricane to tropical storm with 70 mph winds.
Torrential rain hit eastern Bahamas, Turks and Caicos Islands, and Haiti.
Hanna's path and strength uncertain, but could make landfall as major hurricane.
Forecasters predict it could make landfall on southeastern US coast by Friday evening.

Here are the highlights:

Taliban fighters pose in uniforms of 10 French soldiers killed in August ambush.
Photos published in French magazine Paris Match spark angry response.
Taliban commander claims responsibility for attack, says it was "legitimate" defense.
French Defense Minister accuses magazine of promoting Taliban, calling it "voyeurism".

Here are the highlights:

Three masked men stole four Impressionist paintings worth $163 million from a Zurich museum.
The stolen paintings include works by Monet, Cezanne, Degas, and Van Gogh.
The thieves entered the museum at 4:30 p.m. and threatened staff before escaping.
A $91,000 reward is offered for information leading to the return of the paintings.

Here are the highlights:

A humanitarian plane carrying 17 people crashed in the Democratic Republic of Congo during a storm.
The plane was on a routine flight from Kinshasa to Goma with three stops.
Search and rescue crews lost contact with the plane near Bukavu and found debris 9.4 miles northwest.
All occupants of the Beechcraft 1900 plane are believed to have died, according to Air Serv International.

Flash floods and landslides triggered by Tropical Storm Kammuri kill at least 100 people in Vietnam.
Flooding damaged tens of thousands of homes, swept away thousands of cattle, and submerged crops.
Over two dozen people remain missing as rescue workers search for survivors.
Heavy rainfall is expected to continue, with more casualties feared.

Here are the highlights:

A Spanair MD-82 airliner crashed on takeoff from Madrid's airport, killing 153 people.
The plane lifted off, veered sharply right, and skidded down the runway, catching fire.
Eighty bodies have been identified, with many too badly burned for fingerprint identification.
The cause of the accident is still unknown, with investigators relying on DNA and flight data recorders.

Here are the highlights:

Roland Martin discusses the importance of fact-checking in journalism.
Rumors can spread quickly and cause harm, as seen in Bernie Mac's death.
Journalists should not push unverified stories to keep up with rumors.
Sticking to facts is crucial to maintaining credibility and integrity.

Three Americans rescued from Colombian jungle captivity left a medical center for home.
Thomas Howes, Keith Stansell, and Marc Gonsalves had been held for over five years.
They urged the media to not forget the hundreds of other hostages still held by FARC.
The trio will spend time with family before resuming public appearances.

Here are the highlights:

President Bush condemns Russia's escalated violence against Georgia, calling it "unacceptable".
Bush met with Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin at the Olympic opening ceremonies.
Vice President Dick Cheney says Russia's aggression against Georgia "must not go unanswered".
Georgia withdraws its forces and offers a ceasefire, which Russia refuses.

Here are the highlights:

Ben Stiller's "Tropic Thunder" is a Hollywood satire that takes chances with its characters and humor.
Robert Downey Jr. plays an Australian actor who surgically dyes his skin to play a black man.
The film challenges stereotypes and features a cast of self-absorbed Hollywood types.
The movie has received praise and criticism, with some disability groups protesting its depiction of people with disabilities.

Here are the highlights:

Hurricane Gustav threatens the Gulf Coast, potentially making landfall as a Category 2 or 3 hurricane.
New Orleans prepares for evacuations, with 2,829 FEMA trailers in the city.
Mississippi Gov. Haley Barbour urges residents to prepare for the worst, with evacuations beginning Saturday.
President Bush declares an emergency in Louisiana, freeing up federal aid and relief efforts.

American Airlines fined $7.1 million for maintenance issues and drug-alcohol testing program problems.
Aircraft flew with known repairs needed, defying safety regulations.
FAA cites inadequate testing and delayed inspections of emergency lighting systems.
American disputes fines, saying they are "excessive" and will appeal.

Here are the highlights:

The US Olympic Committee and IOC ask a federal judge to shut down www.beijingticketing.com.
The site is accused of scamming Olympic ticket buyers, taking credit card and banking information.
The site has sold tickets for the Beijing Olympics, including the opening ceremony, for up to $2,000.
The USOC has received reports of consumers losing up to $57,000 to the scam.

Here are the highlights:

Celebrity chef Bobby Chinn's journey to culinary success was marked by various careers.
He worked on Wall Street, as a stand-up comedian, and in restaurants.
Chinn's break came when Hubert Keller took him on as a volunteer in his kitchen.
He opened his first restaurant in Vietnam in 1995 and now presents "World Café Asia".

Tropical Storm Fay stalled near Cape Canaveral, Florida, bringing heavy rain and flooding to east-central Florida.
Fay could dump 30 inches of rain in some areas, with historic flooding reported in Brevard County.
The storm has made landfall three times, with a possible fourth landfall in northern Florida Thursday.
Fay has maximum sustained winds of 60 mph, with a slow movement towards the northwest.

Here are the highlights:

Five Bolivian states staged a civic strike, protesting against President Evo Morales and demanding more gas revenue.
The strike was called to demand the government return tax revenue to fund regional development.
Confrontations between government supporters and pro-autonomy groups occurred in Santa Cruz, with police firing tear gas.
The strike was part of a long-standing power struggle between Morales and conservative leaders in eastern Bolivia.

Here are the highlights:

Joe Pantoliano attends Democratic National Convention to raise awareness about mental illness.
He's founder and president of No Kidding, Me Too, an advocacy organization.
Pantoliano has met with Obama and McCain camps to promote mental health and recovery.
He's an independent voter, unsure who he'll support.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. John McCain's op-ed on Iraq war policy rejected by The New York Times.
Paper asked for a revised draft with more concrete plans and timelines.
McCain's campaign says his position on Iraq won't change due to NYT demands.
NYT has published at least seven op-eds by McCain since 1996.

Scientists successfully activated the Large Hadron Collider, a $9 billion particle accelerator, in Geneva, Switzerland.
The collider aims to simulate the Big Bang and unlock the universe's secrets, potentially confirming theories on extra dimensions.
Experts hope to find the Higgs boson, a theoretical particle that could explain matter's mass, by 2009.
The experiment may uncover surprises that contradict prevailing theories, but could lead to new discoveries.

Here are the highlights:

Hillary Clinton's convention speech was a work in progress until the last minute.
She redirected her supporters' energy to Barack Obama, urging them to elect him.
Clinton's speech emphasized unity, asking supporters to consider the future of their children and grandchildren.
She gave Obama the seal of approval on health care, promising a plan that covers every American.

Here are the highlights:

Relatives of a crash victim were given wrong remains and asked to return them by authorities.
Error occurred in delivering remains, not in identifying the victim, a judge's investigation found.
Family received urn 104, but was supposed to have urn 134 containing the correct remains.
DNA samples were used to identify 126 victims, with a few dozen families still waiting.

112 US troops have died in Afghanistan in 2008, surpassing the 111 deaths in 2007.
Adm. Michael Mullen warns the US is "running out of time" to win the war in Afghanistan.
The US needs better nation-building initiatives and a stronger cross-border strategy with Pakistan.
585 Americans have died in Operation Enduring Freedom, 506 in Afghanistan.

Rare images of the elusive okapi, a giraffe-like animal, have been released by the Zoological Society of London.
Okapis were thought to be mythical until camera traps captured the first-ever photos of the animal in the wild.
The okapi is native to the Democratic Republic of the Congo and has zebra-like stripes on its rear.
The images show the okapi's unique features, including its long legs and velvety coat.

Russian bombers land in Venezuela for training flights over neutral waters.
Training flights will last several days, with NATO fighters monitoring the exercise.
Russia denies violating international airspace rules, says flights are routine.
Pentagon will monitor the exercise, but sees it as a normal military activity.

Here are the highlights:

Reese Witherspoon, honorary chairman of the Avon Foundation, wants to banish the myth that young women are not at risk for breast cancer.
Every three minutes, a woman in the US is diagnosed with breast cancer, making it a terrifying statistic.
Early detection saves lives, with a 97% five-year survival rate when caught before spreading to other parts of the body.
Women in their 20s and 30s should have a clinical breast exam every three years, and those 40+ every year.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Barack Obama is in excellent health, according to his doctor's statement.
He is an "intermittent" smoker and exercises regularly, jogging three miles.
Obama's doctor, Dr. David Scheiner, has been his primary doctor since 1987.
Obama's health is described as "excellent" with no physical reason he can't serve as president.

US-led forces capture two senior al Qaeda in Iraq leaders, including one suspected of planning Jill Carroll's 2006 kidnapping.
Suspects include Salim Abdallah Ashur al-Shujayri and Ali Rash Nasir Jiyad al-Shammari.
Abu Uthman suspected of masterminding Carroll's abduction, while Abu Tiba oversaw al Qaeda attack cells.
Captured men suspected of planning car bombings and kidnappings, and providing weapons and explosives.

Lauren Burk, 18, found shot on Auburn University campus, dies at hospital.
Courtney Larrell Lockhart, 23, charged with capital murder in her killing.
Police investigate arson and kidnapping in connection with her death.
Memorial service planned for Monday on Auburn University campus.

Here are the highlights:

Drivers in Houston, Texas, are panicking at gas stations, causing long lines and chaos.
Gas prices jumped 57 cents per gallon overnight in Milton, Ontario, Canada.
Some stations are imposing limits, such as a 10-gallon limit at a Kangaroo Express station.
Rumors of $6-per-gallon gas caused a panic in Sylva, North Carolina, with police called in to maintain order.

Here are the highlights:

Coalition troops hand over security control of Anbar province to Iraqis, marking a major victory against al-Qaeda.
U.S. troops will remain in the province to support Iraqi forces, shifting their mission from combat to support.
Anbar is the 11th province to revert to local security control, with over 25,000 U.S. troops remaining in the area.
The transfer is seen as a major progress for Iraq, with a significant drop in violence and calls for U.S. troop withdrawal.

Here are the highlights:

Robert Rogers' family of six was swept away in a flash flood in 2003.
He survived and now preaches messages of hope and faith to thousands.
Rogers has told his story over 400 times and has established an orphanage in Russia.
He hopes to establish five orphanages worldwide, symbolizing his lost family members.

Here are the highlights:

Russian doomsday cult barricades itself in cave, awaiting end of world in May.
Cult leader Father Pyotr Kuznetsov is in police custody, undergoing psychiatric exams.
29 cult members, including 4 children, are holed up in a ravine in Russia's Penza region.
Temperatures in the cave are below 54°F (12°C), and cult members have threatened suicide.

Here are the highlights:

Six people killed and 13 wounded in shelling of South Ossetia by Georgian forces, officials say.
Georgia initially blamed Russian peacekeepers, but later claimed to have returned fire after being fired upon.
Women, children, and elderly being evacuated from conflict zone due to fears of further violence.
South Ossetia's leader threatens to mobilize volunteers and declare general mobilization if Georgia continues provocative actions.

Zimbabwe's inflation rate soars to 11.2 million percent, highest in the world.
Inflation surges from 2.2 million percent in May, despite government price controls.
A loaf of bread now costs 1.6 trillion Zimbabwe dollars, up from 200,000 in February.
Economic crisis worsens amid political instability and lack of donor support.

Here are the highlights:

The author describes a mysterious and annoying colleague, "The Tinkler", who consistently leaves the office bathroom in a messy state.
The author and her colleagues attempt to deduce The Tinkler's identity, speculating about her habits and motivations.
The author's daydreams take on a Sherlock Holmes-like quality, imagining a dramatic reveal of The Tinkler's identity.
The article concludes with the author's frustration and longing for a more civilized and courteous work environment.

Here are the highlights:

Wildland Firefighter Foundation grants over $1.5 million in aid to over 500 families of injured and fallen firefighters.
Founder Vicki Minor provides emergency assistance, support, and advocacy to wildfire families nationwide.
The foundation helps with medical expenses, travel, and emotional support, as well as benefits and compensation.
Minor hopes her foundation gives firefighters' families "a sense of peace and comfort" in their time of need.

The New York Giants won Super Bowl XLII in a stunning upset over the New England Patriots.
David Tyree's amazing catch set up the game-winning touchdown.
Giants fans celebrate the team's first Super Bowl win in 17 years.
Eli Manning led the Giants to victory, silencing the Patriots' fans.

Here are the highlights:

Deadly Hindu-Christian riots continue in Orissa, India, with 20 deaths reported.
A police officer died after an armed mob torched a police station in Kandhamal district.
Violence spread to southern India, with vandals attacking 14 churches in Karnataka.
Police have arrested 140 people, including 60 Hindus, in connection with the riots.

Here are the highlights:

Bill Clinton's campaign apologizes for his "inappropriate" language about a Vanity Fair article.
The article questioned Clinton's personality change since his 2004 heart bypass surgery.
Clinton called the reporter "scumbag" and "sleazy" for using anonymous sources.
He also accused the reporter of spreading lies about him and his wife's campaign.

Prince William starts 2-month Royal Navy attachment on Monday, part of military experience for future king role.
He'll undergo basic sea safety course, then join HMS Iron Duke in the Caribbean for counter-narcotic operations.
William will also spend time on frigates, mine hunters, submarines, and helicopters during his attachment.

Parma signs Alberto Paloschi from AC Milan in a co-ownership deal.
Paloschi scored on his Milan debut with his first touch in February.
Massimo Oddo, Milan's full-back, may leave for Lyon.
Lyon already has Italian left-back Fabio Grosso, a World Cup winner.

JetBlue flight from Boston to Fort Lauderdale diverted due to fight over smoking in bathroom.
Fight broke out between three people, including two brothers, on board the flight.
One person was taken into custody and another was injured in the face.
Passengers were interviewed by FBI investigators at Raleigh-Durham International Airport.

Here are the highlights:

Army Staff Sgt. Darris J. Dawson, 24, killed by another US soldier in Iraq.
Dawson's father, Darryl Mathis, is angry and wants more information from the military.
The military has classified the death as "non-hostile," citing no hostile enemy action.
Dawson's wife, Maxine, is seeking answers and wants to know why her husband died.

Here are the highlights:

Gov. David Paterson of New York orders state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed in other states and countries.
The directive follows a February court ruling that legal same-sex marriages should be recognized in New York.
The governor's legal counsel sent a memo to state agencies on May 14, 2008.
The memo says failing to recognize gay marriages would violate New York's human rights law.

Here are the highlights:

Residents of Galveston, Texas, are struggling to rebuild after Hurricane Ike's devastating effects.
Wrecked homes and possessions are scattered throughout the city, with some residents allowed to return.
Paula Munoz plans to rebuild her family's El Rey restaurant, saying "We'll rebuild, and we'll do it here."
Maria Patina was relieved to find her house still standing, saying "Thank you, God."

Here are the highlights:

Susana Trimarco's daughter Marita vanished in 2002, suspected victim of human trafficking and prostitution.
Trimarco has spent 6½ years searching, often putting herself at risk, and won accolades worldwide.
Art imitates life as her story becomes the basis of Argentina's popular nighttime soap opera "Vidas Robadas".
The show exposes human trafficking, a topic rarely discussed in Argentina, and has attracted 2 million viewers nightly.

Here are the highlights:

An earthquake struck southern Iceland, causing injuries and damaging roads and buildings.
The 6.1 magnitude quake struck 50 km east-southeast of Reykjavik, 10 km below the surface.
No fatalities reported, but "great material damage" and roads/bridges closed.
Residents described the quake as feeling like the world was ending, with everything "floating around".

An American sailor shot and killed two female sailors before shooting himself at a US military barracks in Bahrain.
The alleged shooter, a male, survived and is in critical condition at a military hospital.
The motive is unclear, but the Navy says the incident is not terror-related and involved only US military personnel.
The base was closed for an hour after the shootings.

Here are the highlights:

More than 100 countries adopt treaty to ban cluster bombs, a weapon that often affects civilians long after conflict ends.
Countries agree to never use, develop, acquire, or transfer cluster munitions and explosive bomblets.
The treaty aims to ban the weapons, protect injured civilians, and clean up contaminated areas.
The agreement requires destruction of stockpiles within eight years and has been hailed as a "great achievement" by campaigners.

Indonesia to withdraw from OPEC at year's end due to declining oil production levels.
Country has become a net importer of oil, unable to meet its OPEC quota.
Indonesia's oil production has decreased by 32% since 1996, according to US Energy Information Administration.
Country's decision not expected to have significant impact on global oil prices.

Here are the highlights:

Navy Rear Adm. John Stufflebeem had an affair with a federal employee, Jane Doe, in 1990.
Stufflebeem falsely told investigators he was a widower, but Jane Doe confirmed the affair.
Stufflebeem was demoted and fired from his post as director of the Navy staff.
He was convicted of making false official statements to investigators.

Two US customs agents arrested for helping smuggle drugs and contraband at JFK Airport.
Customs supervisor and officer face charges of narcotics, bribery, and conspiracy.
Bribes were accepted to allow contraband to pass through undetected, DEA says.
Over 20 people indicted, 600 pounds of drugs seized in sting operation.

Guatemala halts adoption process for 2,000 American families due to concerns of coercion and fraud.
Vietnam also halts adoptions to the US amid allegations of corruption and baby-selling.
US State Department sympathizes with parents but says reviews are necessary to protect children.
Prospective parents face uncertainty and heartache as they wait for resolution.

Here are the highlights:

Three men arrested in connection with Natalee Holloway's 2005 disappearance in Aruba.
Brothers Deepak and Satish Kalpoe and Joran Van der Sloot charged with manslaughter or bodily harm.
New evidence led to the arrests, but details of the evidence were not released.
Aruban prosecutors say the men were the last to be seen with Holloway before her disappearance.

Here are the highlights:

Myanmar's neighbors China and India accused of not doing enough to aid cyclone victims.
ASEAN criticized for not pressuring Myanmar's junta to allow international aid.
Myanmar's government criticized for slow response to cyclone, with over 40,000 reported dead.
ASEAN experts to assess disaster and aid needs in Yangon, Myanmar.

Here are the highlights:

Xenophobic violence in South Africa's Cape Town leaves over 40 dead, 420 foreign nationals evacuated.
Clashes overnight result in one death, 15 arrests, and 12 minor injuries.
Foreigners flee to community centers and churches, with over 2,000 seeking refuge.
South African President Thabo Mbeki deploys army to stop attacks.

Here are the highlights:

Former Illinois Gov. George Ryan and co-defendant Larry Warner lost a Supreme Court appeal.
They will remain in prison for racketeering and fraud convictions.
Ryan reported to a Wisconsin prison in November to serve a 6½-year sentence.
Their lawyers claimed trial judge improperly removed jurors during deliberations.

Rebel group MEND claims responsibility for oil pipeline attack in Nigeria, killing 11 government soldiers.
MEND says it sabotaged Shell pipeline, killed soldiers, and found gang-raped girls.
Nigerian military disputes death toll, calls claim "pure propaganda".
Rebel group seeks greater share of oil wealth for Niger Delta residents.

Here are the highlights:

• Augusten Burroughs recommends "The Member of the Wedding" by Carson McCullers, a stunningly evocative book.
• Jackie Collins suggests "Whacked" by Jules Asner, a delicious tale of revenge set in L.A.
• Nelson Demille recommends "The Prince" by Niccolò Machiavelli, a great help for dealing with difficult people.
• Elizabeth Gilbert recommends "The Principles of Uncertainty" by Maira Kalman, a quirky year-in-the-life story.

Here are the highlights:

Former Labor Secretary Robert Reich endorses Sen. Barack Obama for president.
Reich praises Obama's plans for Social Security and healthcare reform.
Two former Democratic senators, Sam Nunn and David Boren, also endorse Obama.
Obama says the endorsements will be important sources of advice and counsel.

Here are the highlights:

Researchers reprogrammed human skin cells to act like embryonic stem cells, sparking debate over funding and ethics.
President Bush's stance on embryonic stem cell research is vindicated, White House says.
Alternative methods could avoid destroying human embryos, say proponents of the new research.
Federal funding for embryonic stem cell research remains a contentious issue.

Josef Fritzl confessed to imprisoning his daughter for 24 years and fathering seven of her children.
He twice holidayed in Thailand while his daughter remained trapped in a cellar below his house.
Fritzl's holiday companion said he bought lingerie and evening dresses for a "very slim woman" in Pattaya, Thailand.
Fritzl's daughter and two of her children were reunited with three other children and her mother after being held captive for 24 years.

Here are the highlights:

Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah assures Lebanon of cooperation in political life, rejecting control or governance.
Lebanon's parliament elects Michel Sleiman as president after six-month vacancy.
Nasrallah calls for national partnership with no eliminations or impositions, citing a new era and start.
Hezbollah agrees to end sit-in protest, gaining veto power in new Cabinet.

Here are the highlights:

A Texas appeals court ruled the state had no right to remove children from a polygamist sect's ranch.
Children are likely to be returned to their parents, says CNN legal analyst Jeffrey Toobin.
The children are "hurting very badly" and feel betrayed by adults, according to their mother.
The Texas Child Protective Services Department is working on a response to the court ruling.

Here are the highlights:

A cheaper car's sticker price may not always mean lower ownership costs over time.
A $17,500 Mitsubishi Lancer may cost $3,000 more to own than a $22,500 Mini Cooper.
Depreciation is the biggest factor in ownership costs, accounting for 48% of the total.
Fuel costs are the second-biggest factor, accounting for 21% of the total.

Roland Martin says presidential candidates will never be "regular folks" due to their elite backgrounds.
Sen. Barack Obama, Sen. Hillary Clinton, and Sen. John McCain all attended elite universities.
The candidates' wealth and health care benefits set them apart from average Americans.
They are not "one of us" and should focus on policies that benefit the middle class.

Carmen Salva leads a youth environmental group, Esperanza de Vida, to clean up the mountains in northern Argentina.
The group collects 60 bags of trash for recycling on an average Saturday cleanup.
Llamas help carry the heavy load down from the mountains, earning them the nickname "little eco-llamas."
The group's efforts raise awareness, add new volunteers, and implement new projects to protect the environment.

Sixty-four measles cases reported in the US this year, most in seven years.
All but one case involved unvaccinated individuals, mostly due to age or lack of shots.
Fifty-four cases were imported from other countries, mainly Europe and Israel.
Fourteen patients were hospitalized, but no deaths were reported.

Here are the highlights:

Amnesty International's annual report criticizes human rights abuses in China, US, and Russia.
China's human rights record worsened in 2007 with increased repression and censorship.
US criticized for Guantanamo Bay detentions and executions, with 42 people put to death.
Amnesty urges governments to act on human rights promises and end repression.

Here are the highlights:

A judge declared a mistrial in the retrial of six men accused of plotting with al Qaeda.
Narseal Batiste, the alleged ringleader, testified he wasn't serious about the threats.
The decision marks the second time government prosecutors failed to convict the defendants.
The "Liberty City 7" may face a third trial if prosecutors decide to pursue charges.

US Customs and Border Patrol agent Luis Aguilar killed in Arizona while trying to stop suspected narcotics smugglers.
He was struck by a car driven by a suspected smuggler in the Imperial Sand Dunes Recreation Area.
Both vehicles drove back into Mexico after the incident, which occurred near the California-Arizona border.
Federal and Mexican authorities are working together to apprehend the suspected killers.

Here are the highlights:

A Colorado woman, Rozita Swinton, is being pursued as a "person of interest" in a Texas polygamist ranch raid.
She was arrested for false reporting and has no connection to the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
Phone calls to a crisis center in Texas triggered the raid, claiming a 16-year-old girl was abused.
Evidence found at her home may link her to the calls, but authorities are still searching for the alleged victim, Sarah.

Here are the highlights:

Denzel Washington credits his childhood at the Boys & Girls Club with changing his life's direction.
Nearly 30% of this year's freshman class will drop out of high school, with 40% in urban areas.
The obesity rate for kids has increased by 300% since 1980, triggering health problems.
Youth account for 20% of violent crimes in the US, with peak crime rates at 3-4 pm.

Thousands protest against China's human rights record and Tibet crackdown in San Francisco.
Protesters chant and wave flags outside Chinese consulate, demanding "Stop killing" and "No human rights, no Olympics".
The Olympic flame is being kept in an undisclosed location ahead of a 6-mile relay in San Francisco.
Protests have also occurred in London and Paris, with dozens arrested and the torch relay disrupted.

Frankie Dettori, a jockey, opened a restaurant with chef Marco Pierre White in 2004.
The restaurant has four locations worldwide, with a cookbook released in March.
Dettori shares his favorite recipe, Parmigiana di Melanzane, a vegetarian dish.
The recipe is a family favorite, reminiscent of childhood Sunday lunches.

Here are the highlights:

Middlesbrough releases Fabio Rochemback, Gaizka Mendieta, and Dong Gook Lee from the team.
Rochemback scored a long-range free-kick in his final game against Manchester City.
Mendieta struggled to regain his place in the team after joining on a free transfer.
Lee scored only twice in 11 starts and 18 appearances for Middlesbrough.

Here are the highlights:

Birmingham City co-owner David Sullivan and MD Karren Brady interviewed by police in corruption probe.
Investigation focuses on payments to football agent and two players dating back to 2002-03.
No allegations of financial benefit to club or directors; club cooperating with police.
Trading on London Stock Exchange temporarily suspended due to investigation.

Here are the highlights:

• Rancher Warner Glenn took the first photo of a live jaguar in the US in 1996 in Arizona.
• The jaguar's breeding population in northern Mexico is estimated to be fewer than 120.
• The US-Mexico border fence may stop the possible return of breeding jaguars to the US.
• Conservationists worry the fence will harm wildlife and hinder their study of the elusive cats.

Sudan and Chad sign non-aggression agreement to halt cross-border hostilities.
Talks facilitated by Senegalese President Abdoulaye Wade and UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon.
Agreement aims to normalize relations and halt rebel faction movements.
UN to monitor and ensure implementation of the deal.

Here are the highlights:

Viktor Bout charged with conspiring to sell weapons to Colombian rebel group FARC to kill Americans.
Accused of selling missiles, rockets, and other weapons to FARC between 2007 and 2008.
FARC is designated a terrorist organization by the US State Department.
Bout's assets in the US were frozen in 2004 for violating US government restrictions.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Hillary Clinton's chief strategist Mark Penn quits amid criticism over Colombia trade deal contacts.
Penn's public relations firm met with Colombian government, sparking controversy.
Penn apologizes for "error in judgment" and says he will not repeat it.
Clinton's campaign manager Maggie Williams says Penn will continue to advise the campaign.

Thousands protest against China's human rights record and Tibet crackdown in San Francisco.
Protesters chant and wave flags outside the Chinese consulate, demanding "Stop killing" and "No human rights, no Olympics".
The Olympic flame is kept in an undisclosed location ahead of a 6-mile relay in San Francisco.
Protests have occurred in London and Paris, with dozens arrested and the torch's passage halted.

Skybus Airlines is shutting down due to rising jet fuel costs and a slowing economy.
The airline will cease operations effective Saturday, making it the third to do so this week.
ATA and Aloha Airlines also announced shutdowns earlier this week due to financial issues.
Passengers with reservations for Saturday and beyond can seek refunds from credit card companies.

Here are the highlights:

A US sailor, Olatunbosun Ogbogu, arrested for robbery and murder of Japanese taxi driver in Yokosuka.
Ogbogu, a 22-year-old Nigerian national, was handed over to Japanese authorities at Yokosuka Naval Base.
The incident sparked controversy amid reports of US service members committing crimes in Japan.
US ambassador to Japan, Thomas Schieffer, vowed to ensure justice is served in the matter.

Here are the highlights:

Keanu Reeves stars as a rogue cop in "Street Kings", a Cop Noir film with a familiar story.
The movie follows Detective Tom Ludlow, a troubled cop with a penchant for violence.
Ludlow's investigation into a cop's murder leads him to uncover a conspiracy.
He must navigate the corrupt system while dealing with his own personal demons.

Here are the highlights:

Texas authorities investigating safety of children at polygamist sect leader Warren Jeffs' ranch.
Ranch in Eldorado, Texas, has been sealed off, and no one is allowed to enter or leave.
Authorities have not determined a safety issue with the children, but an investigation is ongoing.
Several law enforcement agencies are assisting with the investigation.

Mikhail Gorbachev says Georgia provoked conflict in South Ossetia, calls it a "barbaric assault".
Gorbachev claims Russia moved troops to stem violence, not to dismantle Georgia's democracy.
Georgia's President Saakashvili accuses Gorbachev of "vindicating lies and deceptions".

At least 19 schoolgirls died in a fire at Buddo Junior School in Mpigi, west of Kampala.
Fire erupted in the dormitory late Monday, with 42 girls surviving.
Authorities found two adult bodies in the ashes, with cause of fire unknown.
Police investigating, with conflicting reports on whether doors were locked or not.

US believes Pakistan's spy service supported deadly bombing of India's Embassy in Afghanistan.
Pakistan denies allegations, saying evidence is unfounded and an effort to malign the ISI.
The US has intercepted communications between Pakistani intelligence officers and militants.
Pakistan and Afghanistan have a tumultuous past, with Pakistan's ISI accused of supporting militants.

Here are the highlights:

Gloria Taylor, mother of murdered schoolboy Damilola, dies of suspected heart attack at 57.
She collapsed while walking with her husband in south-east London and was pronounced dead at hospital.
Damilola, 10, was stabbed and bled to death in 2000 after being attacked on his way home from school.
Gloria established the Damilola Taylor Trust to improve lives of underprivileged young people.

Pope Benedict XVI arrives in the US for a six-day, two-city visit.
He is greeted by President Bush, first lady Laura Bush, and their daughter Jenna.
The visit is the first US papal visit since the 9/11 attacks and Benedict's first to the US.
The pope will speak at the White House and address the UN General Assembly.

Eight Florida teenagers, six girls, will be tried as adults for beating a 16-year-old girl in a video.
The suspects face life in prison for kidnapping and battery, with three also charged with tampering with a witness.
The attack was allegedly in retaliation for insults posted online, with the teens planning to post the video on YouTube.
The victim remains hospitalized with blurred vision, hearing loss, and a swollen face.

Here are the highlights:

Heather Mills' finances questioned, lack of documentary evidence supporting her claims of wealth in 1999.
Judge rejects Mills' claim of being a wealthy person in 1999, finds her case "wholly exaggerated".
Paul McCartney lent Heather Mills £360,000 annual allowance, plus £1 million in cash and £842,000 to her sister.
Judge awards Mills £24.3 million, less than her requested £50 million, citing her "me, too" attitude.

Here are the highlights:

Sarah Knox Taylor Davis was the daughter of President Zachary Taylor and died of malaria at 21.
Elizabeth Harrison Walker was a lawyer and investment expert who wrote a monthly newsletter.
Margaret Woodrow Wilson was a musician who gave recitals for the Red Cross and performed in France during WWI.
Elizabeth Ann Christian Blaesing was the daughter of President Warren G. Harding's mistress and was adopted by her aunt and uncle.
